title_review: Fantastic & Fun  Vegetarian/Vegan while in Madrid
review_preview: Visited twice, once for coffee, smoothie, and a burger while waiting to check into our apartment rental in Malasana.  Decided to dine here on our last eve in Madrid as the food is very fresh, atmosphere and decor fun, and great service.  We don't each...
review_full: Visited twice, once for coffee, smoothie, and a burger while waiting to check into our apartment rental in Malasana. Decided to dine here on our last eve in Madrid as the food is very fresh, atmosphere and decor fun, and great service. We don't each much meat as we are pescaterian/flexiterian - Ha! Superchulo offers a great menu with lots of options. Husband and son got the Mr Burger, I had a salad and pizza. All were outstanding. They also offer microbrewed beers by Chula...very good for those seeking something with some body. The service was attentive w/o being overbearing. Paco, our waiter, was personable and offered great beer pairings. Desserts were great, too. Menu available online as are reservations. Popular place because it is so good!!

They brought out our check before we said we wanted it, and in the end they told us to leave because they needed the table. This happened after we’d only stayed there for one hour, and we even had a reservation. We wanted to order more, but ended up not doing it because we felt that we weren’t welcome. Unbelievably rude staff, and they gave us a really uncomfortable experience. Would not recommend going there, and it ruined the good night it was supposed to be.

This turned out to be true but was vastly overshadowed by the despicable manner in which we were treated.  From the beginning to the end we were made to feel extremely unwanted, despite having a reservation. We were forced to order within ten minutes of seating despite being a group of six, and for some of us had our plates taken away before we had even finished our meal. We were made to pay before even finishing our drinks and then were told shortly after by the waiter that he needed the table despite having only been there for an hour by this point.  It’s such a shame that we were made to feel this way given how nice the food was, but we definitely will not be returning and I encourage others to choose somewhere else if they want to be treated like a human being.

Might want to review the basics of the food and customer service. Only highlight was the waitress who brought the drinks over who was super friendly. Will we be going back.... No. Thousands of other places to choose from (including Vegie) in this vibrant city.

review_preview: I have visited Superchulo several times, typically when I can't get a table anywhere else. Superchulo is always my backup, but it almost always ends up being better than the original plan.The place is huge and modern. There are plants (real or fake?) hanging...
review_full: I have visited Superchulo several times, typically when I can't get a table anywhere else. Superchulo is always my backup, but it almost always ends up being better than the original plan. The place is huge and modern. There are plants (real or fake?) hanging from the ceiling and the restaurant extends downstairs and around several corners. Everything is decorated nicely and instagram-worthy.  The restaurant is entirely vegetarian (no meat at all) with lots and lots of vegan options. I love that every item on the menu tells you what allergens it contains (soy, lactose, sulfites, etc.). I also love that each item tells you if it's possible to make it vegan - for example, if you want the veggie burger to be vegan, then it tells you just to ask for it without cheese.  Most of the menu stays the same during the year, but the soups and salads are constantly changing with the season. I love that they offer a cold soup in the summers and a hot one in the winters. I also love that their salads are not the typical lettuce and tomato that you typically receive in Spain. Their salads are bowls of various vegetables, legumes, and grains.  Most recently, I came with two friends. I ordered a winter buddha bowl - the pop-eye with a garlic vegan alioli, roasted asparagus, greens, over a huge bed of black quinoa. I ordered it with tofu and roasted sweet potatoes (all for 10.50). The asparagus was a little oily but the flavors were excellent and the alioli is the best alioli I've ever had anywhere! It was a huge quantity and I took the leftovers to work for lunch the next day.  My friends ordered the flower power pizza and another winter buddha bowl - the pink one with beetroot and rice. They finished everything and agreed it was delicious. I've previously had the green bao buns. They are phenomenal. I love sticky buns. There are only two but they are quite large and extremely filling. In fact, I would have been satisfied with only one. My friend this time ordered the pad thai and enjoyed it a lot. The quantity was satisfactory for him. Especially since we had shared the mini pizzas - which are incredibly decadent and filling.  I've also had one of their large salad bowls with falafel. The salad was excellent, however, I found the falafel almost inedible. It was too dense and dry. I can't recommend any get the falafel here. It was served with their homemade crackers which are phenomenal. My friend this time had the barbacoa pizza with their fake meat. My friend enjoyed the pizza but said it was very filling and they were a little unsure about the fake meat. We also had the soup of the day which we liked a lot. Unfortunately, there are not many vegan desserts to choose from. However, I am usually too full from my meal to want dessert anyway, so it is no problem for me. The service can be a little slow, but that is typical in Spain.  In short, I can confidently recommend this place to vegans, vegetarians, and omnivores. The atmosphere is relaxing and beautiful, the menu is excellent, and the prices are fair and affordable. Definitely worth more than one visit.

title_review: Fashionable veggie restaurant in a cute neighbourhood
review_preview: We ate here on a Sunday evening after researching vegetarian restaurants in Madrid. The staff were very friendly and the decor of the restaurant was trendy and quirky, but we were seated at a small table for two in the front corner and I had...
review_full: We ate here on a Sunday evening after researching vegetarian restaurants in Madrid. The staff were very friendly and the decor of the restaurant was trendy and quirky, but we were seated at a small table for two in the front corner and I had a bare light bulb hanging 10 cm above my forehead, which was bit distracting and was unflattering for photos. It was a nice location for watching people walk past the large windows, though.  We were there at about 6:30pm, and were given the smaller Breakfast and Lunch menu; the dinner menu doesn't start until 7pm. We each had pizzas - the Margarita Presumida and the Pizza Trufada - which were tasty, but sweeter than pizzas tend to be in the UK or US. To drink, we both had the house beer, which turned out to be Heineken. Heineken's fine, but I was expecting a Spanish cerveza as the house beer.  The toilets were very interesting and quirky - the sinks were barrels with taps plumbed in above them.

All of this happened within one hour and we had a reservation!! We were six people and willing to have another drink, but it wasn't even offed! So if you want to have a nice evening I recommend going somewhere else as there are many better and nicer places in Madrid!

review_preview: My rating is based on 3 factors: 1- the place 2- the service 3- the food. 1- The place: located in a hip part of town, the restaurant does not disappoint to carry that vibe. The interior is well done with picturesque aesthetics all around....
review_full: My rating is based on 3 factors: 1- the place 2- the service 3- the food. 1- The place: located in a hip part of town, the restaurant does not disappoint to carry that vibe. The interior is well done with picturesque aesthetics all around. If you appreciate design, this is a good spot. #postoninsta. The only downside was the cleanliness of the restrooms, that could've used some up-keeping. 2- The service: our waiter was very attentive and gave us some great recommendations. In general, the staff did it's best even if they didn't speak English. 3- The food: the food was delightful. We had the paninis to start with, and the curry and flower pizza for our mains. The curry was definitely the star of show. The panini was flavourful and the pizza was good as well. The pizza has vegan cheese which might be an acquired taste for non-vegans out there but overall it was good. In fact, we really enjoyed the place we went back for brunch the next day. All in all, I would highly recommend the restaurant.

In short, I wish I could be more positive in my review but unfortunately, I cannot. There are so many better places in Madrid that one should not lose his time here. Sorry.

title_review: Fun Place to Eat! Definitely a Place for the Locals!
review_preview: Really enjoyed Sala de Despiece. I'm from the US and have been challenged with several meals in Spain....what to eat, where to eat and sometimes, what is it?  A friend that lives in Madrid took us here one night to discover more of the local...
review_full: Really enjoyed Sala de Despiece. I'm from the US and have been challenged with several meals in Spain....what to eat, where to eat and sometimes, what is it? A friend that lives in Madrid took us here one night to discover more of the local culture. Although there is usually a waiting line, we walked right in around 9:45pm and got a primo seat at the end of the counter. Extremely interesting menu with a lot of choices and a wonderful wine list. The place is rather small so not easy to get a seat without waiting. Overall, a fun experience. Loved the prawns, the peppers and the desserts. Also shared a fantastic bottle of wine. Give it a try and experience food at its best with the locals!

title_review: Not for everyone, but if you like octopus, this place is for you!
review_preview: One of my goals in Spain was to have a really good octopus (pulpo) dinner. Stop reading if this is not of interest to you! However, if it is, then go on. All over Spain, octopus is on the menus, but you never know what...
review_full: One of my goals in Spain was to have a really good octopus (pulpo) dinner. Stop reading if this is not of interest to you! However, if it is, then go on. All over Spain, octopus is on the menus, but you never know what you're going to get, and it's definitely on the expensive side, so I was hesitant to spend a lot of money and not be satisfied. After looking at a lot of places, this one appealed to me, partly because it was an octopus specialty restaurant. I guessed right! The price was competitive (it's usually about 16€ for 'Pulpo a la Plancha', which is REALLY the one you want - that's the grilled version, not too greasy, oily, and saucy - just a light marinade to accentuate the subtle flavor of the octopus). As for the texture, it's not subtle at all, of course, but that's why you eat octopus! But, again, because this is a special place, they are serving the freshest, and highest quality, octopus available, and even the texture was quite tender (as tender as octopus can be!). But the flavor? Out of this world, and the serving was enormous; this would have been plenty for two people, no doubt, especially with the enormous whole potato (roasted without the skin) that came with it. The wait staff is very engaging, and clearly loves their product as well. If you're on the lookout for really good octopus right in downtown Madrid, this is the place for you!

review_preview: We were using the Tripadvisor app to find a good restaurant nearby and that place caught our eyes: good reviews and focus on octopus. A perfect combination. :-) And this place won't let you down. It is a nice, relaxed bistro (restaurant tables seemed to...
review_full: We were using the Tripadvisor app to find a good restaurant nearby and that place caught our eyes: good reviews and focus on octopus. A perfect combination. :-) And this place won't let you down. It is a nice, relaxed bistro (restaurant tables seemed to be in another room in the back but not yet open to the public as we came in early). The menu includes dishes with an interesting twist; with simple and tasty seafood as a focus. We also tried the pig ears - not really our thing so we only tasted a bit. The extremely friendly waitress then even offered an alternative as we didn't seem to be happy with our original choice. Overall great service, nice food - a 'down to earth' place with easy online reservation that we can highly recommend if you are spending time in Madrid.

title_review: Great atmosphere, great food, good service
review_preview: I and my colleague found this place by chance while walking around Puerta del Sol looking for a quick lunch.It was a lucky choice.We were both impressed by the original ambient, by the friendly atmosphere and by the buzzing dynamic activity of the...
review_full: I and my colleague found this place by chance while walking around Puerta del Sol looking for a quick lunch. It was a lucky choice. We were both impressed by the original ambient, by the friendly atmosphere and by the buzzing dynamic activity of the attendants. All the personnel is young and seem to really enjoy their work with cheerfulness and attentiveness. As I understand there are three ways to to have a drink and/or a meal: at the bar (sitting on stools); on common tables placed in front of of the bar or in isolated tables situated in the adjoining room. This place seems to be very popular and well frequented by both tourists and locals. After waiting some minutes to find a free place to seat on the common tables in front of the bar we chose cod croquettes and grilled octopus. Even if the place was busy the service was rather quick (compared with other spanish places) and that's important if you don't have much time. The cod croquettes were delicious and delicate (I think the best croquettes I had in Spain!) and the grilled octopus (very good) came with a superb sauce. We couldn't resist to finish it up by dipping in it the bread they brought us. Even the draft beer we had was good (above average). I think it's a good choice for good quality food (even for a quick meal).

The house red wine is descent. Price is reasonable. Great location a few blocks from Puerto del sol.

review_preview: I wanted to try this restaurant fir a long while. They do not get reservations and it's always full so I had not done  it jet.1 . It was very very warm. The AC was on but barely working so it was suffocating.2...
review_full: I wanted to try this restaurant fir a long while. They do not get reservations and it's always full so I had not done it jet. 1 . It was very very warm. The AC was on but barely working so it was suffocating. 2 Yes it's nice but nothing that that special, I have seen similar concepts in Barcelona, Brooklyn and Copenhagen.  It's like an old butchers shop reconverted into a restaurant. Is one of those places with a looong table common fir everybody.  The design is fun and interesting but they coukd have done a but better. 3. The real deal and my BIG ISSUE.  The plates are MINCE. They are tinny portions. Look it's ok, usually in Madrid food even very good food is cheap, you want to make a new interesting concept and the kind of food you make is not cheap, Fine ! My issue is that everywhere says that you eat here fir 25 euros, and it says that because that's what they pretend you to believe. The food is interesting and good. But you will have to order a lot of plates if you want to leave the place reasonable satisfied because the portions are ridiculously small. I would recommend the octopus because is really good and reasonable size. The butter fish because it was awesome and the sardines with eggplants. But to be sincere, I won't return I felt cheated is just a trendy place and that's all. Trends pass. If you want good modern cuisine try Kitchen 154 in Mercado ValleHermoso. That is so much better .

This was what one could call "experimental" food with blow torches and twists. Grilled octopus "tail", a huge ball of burrata, lightly seared lamb pieces, shredded beef wrapped in a white blanket which when blow torched melted I cannot recall what the white film. All the dishes were tasty. Within 20 minutes of arriving the place was packed to the brim, it was a squashy lunch. Worth a visit and at half the cost (but equally good quality produce) of a heston blumenthal experience !

title_review: Outstanding interior, a good twist for traditional market food.
review_preview: In general, a place I like to recommend to my foreigner friends when they visit Madrid, because it puts Spanish restaurants in the best position. Market food made of outstanding ingredient quality plus creative take on traditional food from the whole country. And the interior...
review_full: In general, a place I like to recommend to my foreigner friends when they visit Madrid, because it puts Spanish restaurants in the best position. Market food made of outstanding ingredient quality plus creative take on traditional food from the whole country. And the interior is just gorgeous. Service was fine, they explained everything correctly and offered good suggestions. In a perfect world, the waiters wouldn't seem so anxious to make you order more drinks. They ask you so frequently if you want another drink that it seems like you are not supposed to be there if you don't have many beers or wines. That, together with that trendy speedy music, it kind of makes it stressful! But, this is just what happens in every trendy restaurant nowadays, rotation rules, sala Despiece isn't worst. Overall, a very satisfying experience! Congrats!

It has truffle and tomato pastes on the sides. So yummy.

title_review: High quality octopus and tapa dishes
review_preview: We were very happy with our tapa order of the pulpo (octopus), navajas (razor clams), with cana con gaseosa (small beer with soda water).  The octopus came out warm and tasted fresh.  The navajas were grilled to perfection.  And the beer was finally a little...
review_full: We were very happy with our tapa order of the pulpo (octopus), navajas (razor clams), with cana con gaseosa (small beer with soda water). The octopus came out warm and tasted fresh. The navajas were grilled to perfection. And the beer was finally a little malty, unlike other places. Bread was 1 euro extra, which we were happy to not order since we have been eating too much bread from having tapas at other places (which always came with a little bit of meat on a lot of bread). While the prices may seem high initially, the portions of pulpo and navajas were perfect to serve the four of us.

title_review: Small place, Small portions. Staff invited us to leave
review_preview: I decided to visit this restaurant during my stay in Madrid. I had the opportunity to visit Madrid many times before and almost all the experiences I've had there were very nice. This is not the case. The menu has not much variety, but at...
review_full: I decided to visit this restaurant during my stay in Madrid. I had the opportunity to visit Madrid many times before and almost all the experiences I've had there were very nice. This is not the case.  The menu has not much variety, but at least everything is vegan.  The question is what you get for what you pay. The portions are really small. From the hamburgers to the "to share/compartir" items. For example, I ordered "patatas com salsas" for 7Eur. They brought 10 slices of roasted potatoes to the table and they were already cold... In any corner in Madrid you find better than this. The hamburgers, I would classify them as nothing special... and again, small and a kind of undressed. 10Eur. I didn't see the menu before and I was expecting to have a bit more of Spanish vegan flavours, instead, they focus on hamburgers and hot dogs. Not the kind of experience I look for. But the biggest issue, the thing that really bored me, was that the staff brought the bill to the table without I have asked for it. They said they had reservations... but the place was actually empty and I didn't spot anyone around waiting... They essentially invited us to leave. Really unpleasant.  Just to finish my review. I would not recommend this place. Food is average and it is not representative of the nice spanish flavours you may find in other vegan restaurants in the city.  There are many other veg options in the neighborhood. Just avoid a bad experience not going to Distrito Vegano.

title_review: A great find that has been under noticed...but not for long
review_preview: My wife noticed this place while we were walking past it. We are both avid foodies and just love it when we find a winner. This place is the real deal. The owner oversees a very hard working and compitent staff and it shows with...
review_full: My wife noticed this place while we were walking past it. We are both avid foodies and just love it when we find a winner.  This place is the real deal. The owner oversees a very hard working and compitent staff and it shows with his busy restaurant.  Our meal started out with a nice wedge of Spanish Tortilla. It was thick and had nicely sliced poatoes and bits of jamon inside. If you like octopus, la pulperia's octopus is tnder, juicy and the portions are generous. Drizzled with olive oil and accompanied with a simple wedge of lemon. If you try this place, you cant miss this dish. We also ordered a plate of whole grilled squids which were also cooked perfectly. It was served with some type of aoli mayonnaise and lemon. The trick to cooking these babies are to make sure you dont over cook them, as they continue to cook even after you take them off the grill.  We had their house salad too. It had a beautiful grade of tuna flaked on top and the curly escarole and nicely ripenned tomatoes added to its tastiness. We also ordered a meat empinada. The empinada needed some work however, as it was rather tasteless, under seasoned and dry. We ended our meal by sharing their torta santiago, a simply prepare country almond tart. This was accompanied with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. All in all, we loved the meal and would go back in a heart beat. We higly recommend this place.

We paid around 25 euros per person which were more than fair for the price-quality ratio.

review_full: After reading the reviews on here, my friend and I wanted to try this place out for ourselves!! Staff are very friendly, broken English but that was ok, we attempted some spanish! We ordered the 3 dips and bread for starter, the mango humous was definitely our favourite! For main we had the American hotdog and the Mexican burger. We weren't given any cutlery, even after trying to get the waiters attention for quite a while! So it was a very messy ordeal! No condiments were offered either so the hot dog was quite dry, we seemed to have been left to our own devices in the corner! It was a nice meal but as I said in the heading we were blown away and the fact we didn't have any cutlery annoyed us some what. We are pleased we went but probably wouldn't return.

review_preview: My wife is a vegan and while we were in Madrid we decided to visit this small restaurant not far from Atocha and the Queen Sofia Museum, in the colorful quarter of Lavapies. The restaurant is really small - 8 tables perhaps, so it´s a...
review_full: My wife is a vegan and while we were in Madrid we decided to visit this small restaurant not far from Atocha and the Queen Sofia Museum, in the colorful quarter of Lavapies. The restaurant is really small - 8 tables perhaps, so it´s a good idea to make a reservation before. It´s also clearly a family-run business, so there is a very nice homey atmosphere. However, the most important is the food - surely the best vegan food I have ever eaten. In fact, I am not a vegan but I loved it so much that I could easily live without meat for the rest of my life if all restaurants were like Distrito Vegano. We shared some "Croquetones de la Abuela", which are without any doubt one of the fines, yummiest piece of food I have eaten for a long time. And the same can be said about the Nachos - they were beyond belief. As a piece of resistance, I had a cake with edible violets which was simply extraordinary. On top of that the service was friendly, efficient, fast, and the bill much cheaper than we expected. Highly recommended place whether you are a vegan or not.

review_preview: Where do I even start. Food is my top priority and I'm always seeking out new & interesting restaurant experiences. I have to say that this meal has topped my list for 2015. The place is tiny and you may have to wait - if...
review_full: Where do I even start. Food is my top priority and I'm always seeking out new & interesting restaurant experiences. I have to say that this meal has topped my list for 2015.  The place is tiny and you may have to wait - if you go at peak time/days be prepared to get very intimate with your fellow patrons. And there is a possibility you'll be standing up to eat. Buuuut...It all lends itself to the experience.  The menu is extensive, we shared 5 small plates between two, plus dessert. Everything we ordered was simple, interesting and just sensational testing. The ingredients were all super fresh and prepared right in front of you. Do not miss the beef carpaccio with truffle...this was the highlight of the evening.  Lovely food, wine, service and atmosphere. I'd give it 6 stars if I could.

Every single dish was better than we expected, great presentation and fantastic flavours...... but it was the little things that made this restaurant stand out. Firstly a simple glass of cava as we sat down. Then once we had ordered some free gazpacho and dips to keep us entertained until the main courses arrived. Fantastic service throughout.  Then a couple of free small desserts and chocolates to finish off. Great, great restaurant. We had their famed pudding of puff pastry layers, dulce de leche filling, all covered with a thick covering of meringue. It was delicious. Not for everyone perhaps, but for someone who like a good sweet pudding it is hard to beat!

review_full: As a frequent solo traveler I always want to try everything in a new place and occasionally order 2 mains and resist the temptation to over indulge. Tapas are a great way to get multiple tastes and this restaurant even offers half size portions! The staff's English isn't the best, but they try, and when I order incorrectly I think of it as another pleasant surprise to try something new that I otherwise wouldn't order. Nothing to fear here about picking the wrong dish. The oxtail was decadent, the mushroom croquette perfect, the mozzarella creamy and you can't beat the price of cava! Will definitely be back the next time I'm in town.

review_preview: Came for a weekday lunch, very quiet when we arrived but was very busy by the time we left.  Offered some freshly made and delicious potato crisps whilst perusing the menu which was a nice touch.  So many interesting things on the menu and the...
review_full: Came for a weekday lunch, very quiet when we arrived but was very busy by the time we left. Offered some freshly made and delicious potato crisps whilst perusing the menu which was a nice touch. So many interesting things on the menu and the staff were only too helpful to answer any questions or make suggestions. Great fun to sit at the bar and watch all the dishes being prepped and coming out. The rolex was wonderful, as was the carpaccio rolled with truffle and tomato. Everything that we had I very much enjoyed and if I lived in Madrid I think that I'd probably be back repeatedly until I'd worked my way through the extensive menu. Top class tapas!

title_review: Very unique - quality exquisite - would come back
review_preview: Looks like a tech butcher shop. All high tops and very crowded - people wait in line to get seated. Come in small groups- max 4 to be comfortable. Has a little bar next door for people to wait - since the wait ( without...
review_full: Looks like a tech butcher shop. All high tops and very crowded - people wait in line to get seated. Come in small groups- max 4 to be comfortable. Has a little bar next door for people to wait - since the wait ( without a reservation) can be over an hour.  Ordered the meat ( expensive for madrid prices ) but the quality is superb.  Sergio ( the guy running the floor - is very amicable and helps with everything. The guy behind the bar ( manager or owner - I'm not sure - does a great job explaining all the dishes - really good at making you hungry.  We tried the tomatoes ( 2 styles ) both are delicious but ask for the one thats the whole tomato. We also ordered the tuna seared ( must order - would re order 20 times if i could) . Tried the artichokes - perfect blend of flavors. We also tried the steak tartar ( by far the best thing on the menu ). Wine is mostly Spanish in option - the white was drinkable at a normal price. The red (Caecus) goes well with the meat and at a reasonable/moderately priced. Great new trending spot.

review_preview: There is one big problem in Sala de Despiece : it is always VERY crowded, no resevations are accepted and the place is rather small and there are no tables. Sure , the place is rather meant as many others in the zone a tapa...
review_full: There is one big problem in Sala de Despiece : it is always VERY crowded, no resevations are accepted and the place is rather small and there are no tables.  Sure , the place is rather meant as many others in the zone a tapa ' s place. But what tapas- WOW! A rather young crowd from all over the world in a funny technohousemusic like atmossphere serves the best what Spain has to offer. Fabalous seafood tapas like red prawns, langostinos. white asparagus from Navarra sort cooked and glazed with a honey like gelatine. Carpaccio with a fab fresh mayu sauce and olive truffle cream. Wrinkled potatoes from Canary Islands with elegant tops and black truffles, small golden thistles prepared as tempura. Wow fantastic. Wines by the glass or by the bottle at very fair prices per bottle. We had a white wine - yes- from Mallorca called Quibia....very good as old malloqunian grapes like Callet are just getting rediscovered now. Fab experience but need patience to conquer a space......

review_preview: If you are in Madrid don't miss this relatively new tapas bar. It opens at 8pm in the evening and there is always a queue outside. We got to the front by being early and it was well worth it. Within minutes the place was...
review_full: If you are in Madrid don't miss this relatively new tapas bar. It opens at 8pm in the evening and there is always a queue outside. We got to the front by being early and it was well worth it. Within minutes the place was packed and entrance was only allowed when someone left. despite it being busy the staff were well organised and slick with their service. The dishes were original, different and excellent, the variety very good and the staff well versed in what was in each menu item. As you would expect there was beer and wine to accompany the food and it was only slightly more expensive than the more traditional tapas bars. We had a great evening and did not feel rushed or pressured to leave even though there was a queue outside. This is the kind of place you will always remember.

title_review: Marketing Gimmick if you ask me
review_preview: I called this restaurant for a week with a hope that someone will pick up the phone but no success. And you can not reserve for inside the restaurant. So, we took the decision to go there on a Saturday night. I thought okay let's...
review_full: I called this restaurant for a week with a hope that someone will pick up the phone but no success. And you can not reserve for inside the restaurant. So, we took the decision to go there on a Saturday night. I thought okay let's go and see if too crowded, we do something else. At the door, this young lady explained us that it was full and the waiting time was minimum 1 hour and it could be more but she did not know. We said okay like all the other people around us and we were all handed a magic number. I did look at the number in detail. Was it 9 or a 6. So this young friendly lady advised all of us to go for a drink and we all took her advise and went off our own ways to find a place. After 75 minutes, well she said 1 hour, maybe more than 1 hour so 75 minutes was like between 1 and 2 hours. I thought we could maybe wait a bit there and enjoy the food! What a mistake:)So, we were all back. This young nice lady explained us that they were still full and ask our number I showed her our blue paper which said 90:)) and she told all of us that we should wait more. She did not tell us we have no choice and we should leave. She stood there and with her explanations she made us think that there was hope. As it was her job. I have to underline what she said again. She said maybe 1 hour maybe more. She did not know. Same lines again. So we all hoped for 1 hour and 5 minutes I think.  This time I refused to go somewhere and stood in front of the restaurant. Most people went back. Then this young nice lady came and told me "look it's cold here, let me get you two in to the waiting room. That moment we looked each other with my partner with light in our eyes, with more hope, waiting room, we are getting closer. What a mistake! In that moment there were 4 Spanish customers who just came by the door.This young lady againexplained them the system in my view. Guess what, we went into the waiting too  And the waiting room is a tiny room, looks like a tiny demo teaching room and there were already in total 20 people before us :)))... We were at this point starving. We could not give up. Another nice lady there gave us drinks, ofcourse we paid for them. So I checked this waitress notes on the table and in total there were 16 -18 people before us but the system looked complicated . 1 hour later the lady outside came in to announce that in the private room(another room) there was a cancellation and if anyone would like to go there, she would arrange i. I have read about this table on their website and wanted to have a look at it. I went in and saw a huge table in a tiny very uncharming room with 8 very hungry people and empty table. I said no. Then I decided to go out and then have a look at the restaurant and understand our chances of food which at that moment I would have been happy to be served an apple or half a piece of bread. Then suddenly I saw these 4 Spanish clients inside the restaurant which came after us. When asked about it, thisyoung nice lady outside told me that I was completely wrong actually they were before us. You know she might be right. I might have completely made a mistake and I do not want to cause this nice lady her job but let me tell you what else I have seen when I went in. I saw all the 16 people from the waiting room, sitting, standing without a food. And what else , I saw a restaurant fool with people with no food in a very nice decor. There was not any place even tostand. So basically all 90 people before us were there and let me tell you: They All Looke Well, I took my dignity with me or what's is left out of it and my partner and then we left. One of the best decisions I have made to have some self respect for myself.  I can not judge the food or the food service. This young nice lady at the door told me that she has been doing this job for 6 months and she would never risk it by being unfair. At that point I thought that 6 months of experience and you can not tell if a client if they have to wait 1-2 hours or 4-6hours? But it's not her responsibility as she is following a strategy of the owners who tells her don't keep the clients in front of the restaurant, send them for a drink, if they insist then keep them in the room with no air. She is just following the orders. So, if you are clever enough to go before the restaurant opens or on a weekday, let me know how the food tastes.  Good luck!

review_preview: We were positively surprised with this restaurant. We reserved a table for 3 with The Fork app (El Tenedor, in Spain) so we got 30% off in the menu. They'll tell you that each person should choose at least 2 dishes or 1 dish +...
review_full: We were positively surprised with this restaurant. We reserved a table for 3 with The Fork app (El Tenedor, in Spain) so we got 30% off in the menu. They'll tell you that each person should choose at least 2 dishes or 1 dish + 1 dessert. We were hungry so we decided to order 6 dishes and... puff! We couldn't move at the end! The portions are generous and I was everything was amazingly tasty! We had: croquetas de bacalao (cod croquettes), mussels with tomato sauce, breaded dogfish in sauce, grilled squids, octopus with garlic shrimps and finally octopus with "broken" fried eggs and fries.  Should I tell you which one I liked the most? I can't! Try them all! :)

title_review: Authentic from Galicia, cheap with good quality (see photos)
review_preview: When you visit Madrid you gotta know that you don't eat really well anywhere. As in Rome, Paris or many other capitals with great food, you need to know very well where you're going. Severla places gives you low cosrt and bad quality even for...
review_full: When you visit Madrid you gotta know that you don't eat really well anywhere. As in Rome, Paris or many other capitals with great food, you need to know very well where you're going. Severla places gives you low cosrt and bad quality even for sophistacated cuisine and main courses you imagine so delicious.  The Puleria Victoria (pulpo means octopus) is a greta place you can spend only 20 euros with great wine (ask the Ribeiro "vino de la casa" and make them suggest different kinds), deserts and a great discount if you go www.eltenedor.es (we got yesterday a 30% discount). Service is great (ant this is not so common and believe me I know after 10 years in Madrid), air conditioning and a nice atmosphere. Food I suggest you the following: 1) get octopus. I attached photos below of we got. I think best is "a la plancha" (in the pan), not the fried one which has flour and is so heavy. They put oil and basil/rugette on it and it is very very very soft. You will love it. Then we asked the other one with shrimps (gamas). 2) Try "pimientos del padron" (green peppers grilled, one of 20 can be spicy). Very well done.  3) Try navajas (razor clams). Never found any sand or unpleasant sensations. This is soft, with great olive oil. The bread they had was fantastic home-made kind from Galicia.  Deserts are good and authentic as all the rest. See what we had with our friends and ask for it. Cheese and quince is the typical desert they have in Galicia and also typical in Argentina were "Gallegos" took it hundred years ago. Very cheap, high quality and good service.

review_preview: What a meal!We had seen this place on Bizarre Foods and couldn't wait to try it. Luckily for us it was in walking distance from our hotel (Hesperia ). When we walked in we thought we would either have to wait forever or eat...
review_full: What a meal! We had seen this place on Bizarre Foods and couldn't wait to try it. Luckily for us it was in walking distance from our hotel (Hesperia ).  When we walked in we thought we would either have to wait forever or eat standing up. Both of which we would have done seeing the preparation of the food and it being delivered to others. They asked if we minded being seated with others in a room next door. We didn't mind and walked over. It was very cozy and a nice setting. Even though you were sitting with other people you didn't feel like you were.  My wife and I picked out a few things we recognized and asked our waiter Josimar for some other suggestions. He did not disappoint. He spoke English pretty good and made some awesome choices for us.  The presentation and preparation are worth five stars alone!  We had the Rolex. The octopus. The shishito peppers. And some other dishes that were amazing that I cannot remember the name of. The egg yolk and foie gras wrapped in some sort of thinly sliced meat was awesome. But the best was the meal that was like Korean bbq. You can't go wrong mixing up meat and having it blow torched at the table!! Add egg and some Veggie and delicious flavor combined with lettuce wraps and you've got yourself a meal! We spent two weeks prior in Italy to this stop over in Madrid and we agreed this was one of the best meals we had. And....with three beers and three glasses of wine and a TON of food our bill was less than 100 euro! We commented that in the US this type of food and presentation would have been 3 to 4 times this price. Amazing value.  Absolutely recommended if you are in Madrid.  Cannot wait to visit again.

This was definitely the best meal I had in Madrid and one of the best meals I've had in general.

I would love to know how to make them. For dinner, I had the Seafood Paella, and my wife had the Hake. A fantastic dinner!

review_preview: We stumbled across this when looking for something to eat more than tapas.  It is a Galician restaurant so fish and seafood aplenty!Some of us had the fish soup, sizzling prawns and oysters - all very good.I had the Rape (Monkfish) with garlic,...
review_full: We stumbled across this when looking for something to eat more than tapas. It is a Galician restaurant so fish and seafood aplenty! Some of us had the fish soup, sizzling prawns and oysters - all very good. I had the Rape (Monkfish) with garlic, my Husband and friend had the Turbot and my other friend had the Paella. The Monkfish was gorgeous, not killed by garlic and served with potatoes. The Turbot was a good generous portion of two fillets, both well cooked and the delicious (was the feedback). The Paella was cooked for one person (which is unusual), but still served traditionally, brought to the table and then plated up by the waiter. I had to taste it, it was lovely and not too rich.  The décor is typical old Spanish, all very wood based and pictures everywhere of Galician towns etc. There was a number of Spanish families eating when we got there so that is always a good sign and the majority of them were eating seafood or fish. The staff spoke little English but we got by and had a wonderful evening. I would definitely recommend it. Just a quick line to say we went back a couple of days later on a Sunday night very late, and the staff again were very accommodating considering the time - another good night was had by all.

Service is alert and professional, and the waiters dressed nicely. Food choices were many, and all looked appealing.We hade some excellent Calf cutlets from north Spain, tender and very tasty. Further we enjoyed desserts and Cortados (small coffees with a "short" milk) Extensive wine list, fairly priced. We decided for a Reserva Special Pesquera 2003 from Ribera Del Duero. Excellent wine priced only at 40 eur. An enjoyable meal in nice settings.

review_preview: Two nights ago my wife and I asked the front desk for a place close by that serves a good Paella-not one of the many bars that pretend to serve authentic food. Although she didn't know if this restaurant is good she recommended it as...
review_full: Two nights ago my wife and I asked the front desk for a place close by that serves a good Paella-not one of the many bars that pretend to serve authentic food. Although she didn't know if this restaurant is good she recommended it as it is known for its fresh seafood. We tried it and are not sorry we went there.  That night the restaurant had a special. Appetizers, wine, paella, dessert and coffee for 29 Euros. How wrong could we go.  We started with a glass of wine each followed by a smoked salmon plate-enough to be our main course then followed by another appetizers-fish croquettes. My God how would we eat our main meal. The Paella arrived next filled with lovely seafood mixed into what I would call Goa rice. The broth was luscious. Following the main meal which we could not finish we were offered our choice of dessert and coffee. We choose a crepe and ice cream and shared the 2. We were offered coffee and although not on the menu a complimentary liquor. Everything we ate was wonderful. The only complaint was that there was way to much food. The restaurant atmosphere was great. White tablecloths adorned the tables. The service was great, cutlery was replaced with every course. The wait staff and Manager were very attentive.  I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone that wants fresh seafood or anything else.

title_review: By far the best tapas in Madrid
review_preview: Situated in Chamberi, a non-touristy part of Madrid.  Along Calle Ponzano you will find some interesting restaurants and tapas-bars. By far my favorite tapas-bar is “Sala de Despiece” with its wonderful creative interpretations. No tables, you sit at the counter (barra). The best way to...
review_full: Situated in Chamberi, a non-touristy part of Madrid. Along Calle Ponzano you will find some interesting restaurants and tapas-bars. By far my favorite tapas-bar is “Sala de Despiece” with its wonderful creative interpretations. No tables, you sit at the counter (barra). The best way to experience the variety is to follow the recommendations of the very kind and well informed staff (Paul!!). Because of the very high quality of the ingredients and the creativity of the food, this is not a cheap place. Expect to pay for three dishes with two glasses of wine around 50 €. But it is worth every cent. My vegetable starter, a “simple” peeled tomato with deep fried basil, exploded with such an amazing flavor in my mouth, never had vegetable better. All the following courses were surprising and very creative. Try the “Yakuza Bonbon”!

title_review: Foodgasms, Rolex's, theatre and great service for a pittance
review_preview: Totally memorable! Get there 10-minutes before they open, it fills up within 5-minutes! No reservations. You can stand but we enjoyed the privilege of occupying limited seats (there was 4 of us). It was all excellent. The carpaccio and large tomato (so simple but delicious...
review_full: Totally memorable! Get there 10-minutes before they open, it fills up within 5-minutes! No reservations. You can stand but we enjoyed the privilege of occupying limited seats (there was 4 of us). It was all excellent. The carpaccio and large tomato (so simple but delicious - injected with brine maybe?) were particularly good. I also liked the fried egg. We ordered two Rolex's. It's the only dish that was not particularly appetising (the textures were a bit odd) but not awful. You have to order one for the fun factor though - it gets blowtorched at your table! The entire bill came to around €22 per person including 2 drinks each and mine were 2 glasses of champagne. This experience would cost absolute fortune in London. The service was great and the waiters were clearly proud and happy to work there.

review_preview: Went at about 745pm for dinner after seeing this place on an Ainsley Harriet episode a while back. The chairs were all taken at this stage but we were directed to a free bench space and soon seen to by one of the friendly waiters....
review_full: Went at about 745pm for dinner after seeing this place on an Ainsley Harriet episode a while back. The chairs were all taken at this stage but we were directed to a free bench space and soon seen to by one of the friendly waiters. They took our drink order and provided us with some English menus, still slightly difficult to interpret but if you're happy to eat anything you'll be fine. We made a couple of choices and asked for a recommendation to which he advised the beef sirloin was the house favourite. We ordered the confit tomato, the steak tartar, the razor clams and the beef sirloin. It's actually quite hard to put into words how amazing and creative each of these dishes were, they're not fine dining but the creative touches were very cool. All were delicious. It was especially fun when the waiter comes out and cooks the beef sirloin in front of your eyes, not to mention it tastes amazing. The restaurant steadily filled up whilst we were there, and we remained standing for our meal, this in fact did not detract from the experience but instead added to it. Service was also great considering how busy they were. We then went onto have dessert, the waiter called it sweet milk flan and fresh berries. Again simple but delicious. We left happy and full and feeling like we'd been somewhere unlike anywhere else we'd been in Europe. I would definitely recommend a visit but if you need to sit to eat go on the dot of opening.

title_review: Sampling menu of gourmet tapas at reasonable prices
review_preview: We were tired of eating just snacks for lunch after a 9-day trip in Spain and a pocket guide recommended this as ˜a creative eating experience by chef Sergi Arola". We decided that we deserved a treat in one of our last days in Madrid...
review_full: We were tired of eating just snacks for lunch after a 9-day trip in Spain and a pocket guide recommended this as ˜a creative eating experience by chef Sergi Arola". We decided that we deserved a treat in one of our last days in Madrid and went there.  We were delighted by the very modern and relaxed atmosphere of this 6-table restaurant. In the menu, the option of ordering regular dishes or 3 sampling menus of tapas: "Regular" (a re-interpretation of traditional tapas by the chef); "Sea-tapas" (an all-seafood tapas menu) and the "Menu of the day" (a fixed menu allowing you to chose 1 cold tapas, one hot tapas, one salad, one of the main hot dishes in the menu and one desert, all for just 13,90 Euros). We couldn't resist the "Menu of the day" and we did enjoy a creative eating experience as advertised! We can'y wait to go back and taste on of the Tapas sampling menus!

review_preview: Having read about Vi Cool in the Lonely Planet guide we were very excited to try Sergi Arola's modern take on tapas in this contemporary restaurant. After a false start of trying to get a table without a reservation on a Friday night we were...
review_full: Having read about Vi Cool in the Lonely Planet guide we were very excited to try Sergi Arola's modern take on tapas in this contemporary restaurant. After a false start of trying to get a table without a reservation on a Friday night we were able to reserve one for Saturday and it was well worth the wait. The staff are friendly and welcoming, the restaurant busy but not crowded and the customers laid back and relaxed. As for the food, what can I say? It's the best we've tasted in Madrid so far. We decided on the tapas tasting menu for €20 per person so we could sample lots of different dishes but could just have easily ordered of the main menu - everything looked so good! We got to try 6 dishes (including dessert) and there was easily enough food for two. Everything was fantastic but I have to single out the meatballs and potatoes for individual praise. All in all we couldn't fault our visit and I look forward to returning (remembering to book in advance next time) to sample more of the food on offer.

review_preview: We dropped in for lunch at Sergi Arola's ViCool on a cold rainy day in Madrid, conveniently located by Plaza Santa Ana in Huertas. My wife and I are both vegetarian, but were keen to experience this Michelin-rated chef's fare whilst in Spain. As a...
review_full: We dropped in for lunch at Sergi Arola's ViCool on a cold rainy day in Madrid, conveniently located by Plaza Santa Ana in Huertas. My wife and I are both vegetarian, but were keen to experience this Michelin-rated chef's fare whilst in Spain. As a more "casual" format, ViCool offered a more practical and less expensive way to do this as opposed to his signature resturant Sergi Arola Gastronomy. Within the limited veggie choices available, we ordered patatas bravas Arola (his take on bravas, the garlic mayo added a nice twist) and the margerita pizza (heaped with cheese and pieces of buffalo mozzarella). Both dishes were creative and beautifully plated, although portions were small. For desert, we were recommended to try the catalonian cream (which can only be best descibed as a deconstructed cookie with cream and custard) and it didn't disappoint. The service was slow, but friendly and attentive.

title_review: Excellent degustation menu for an incredible Price
review_preview: My second visit to Vi Cool, but this time to taste the degustation menu of 20€ per person (4 people). Before getting there we reserved with the promotion from the website “El Tenedor” (50% of discount), yet once there they told us that it was...
review_full: My second visit to Vi Cool, but this time to taste the degustation menu of 20€ per person (4 people). Before getting there we reserved with the promotion from the website “El Tenedor” (50% of discount), yet once there they told us that it was not applicable for the degustation menu, and instead of it they included the wine pairing for free. As some of us didn´t want to drink wine, they were very pleasant to change the wine for another two drinks by person, free as well. The menu is very complete, it has 9 dishes, from exquisite salads to chocolate with fruit. I would like to remark some dishes. The first are the “bravas by Sergi Arola”, a delicious and new version of the traditional fried potatoes with spicy sauce. Others interesting recipes were the portobello carpaccio, jam croquettes and fried shrimps with curry and mint. As a dessert, what can be better than chocolate with seasonal fruits. In a nutshell, the degustation menu was exquisite, with a great variety, good food and delicious recipes with the right vanguard touch proper to a Michelin chef as Sergi Arola. On the other hand, a constructive criticism will be that the waiters and waitresses were a little bit slow and disorganized.

Service was caring and very good. Recommended.

title_review: Over-hyped  and not worth the money but special food
review_preview: You can order a la carte or take any of the tapas menus. 6 tapas for 2 people, 8 for four, 10 for six. Slight problem we noticed is that the size of the dishes doesn't increase if there are, say, six people at the...
review_full: You can order a la carte or take any of the tapas menus. 6 tapas for 2 people, 8 for four, 10 for six. Slight problem we noticed is that the size of the dishes doesn't increase if there are, say, six people at the table. Only the amount of different dishes increases, which comes as kind of a surprise. Service was impersonal, and although there were 3-4 waiters for a very small restaurant, they weren't around when you needed them. When I asked for a suggestion for wine, the waiter proposed the most expensive bottle on the menu, without any reason. Suggesting only that is in my eyes, very bad taste, and makes clear you are only trying to make money off the restaurant. It wasn't worth the money and half a bottle cost as much as a full bottle of great wine in nearly any other restaurant we went to in Madrid (or Spain for that matter). Aside from that, the tapas are not ordinary (in a good sense), and especially the patatas bravas were incredible. The carpaccio of portobellos with trufle was nice, but the grated cheese they used to mimic a very small amount of white truffle also masked the white truffle flavour, which dimished the value of the dish. We had to wait for one of the waiters to buy a banana to go into our desert dish (freshly cut fruit with warm chocolate to be used as fondue). This dish was kind of pathetic, 1 raspberry, 1 blackberry, more than half was apple, and one strawberry was cut into 7 pieces. As we saw this dish pass to other tables during our meal, we noticed the chocolate fondue bowls seemingly shrink with each new serving. Anyways, if you know this dish is exactly the same for a table of 6, the proportions are not correct, especially given the final price of dinner here.

title_review: Great tapas in a nice relaxed atmosphere
review_preview: We had no reservations for our last night in Madrid as we had to be up very early for a flight. I had read about this place and it was very close to our hotel near plaza Santa Anna. We showed up at 8:30 and...
review_full: We had no reservations for our last night in Madrid as we had to be up very early for a flight. I had read about this place and it was very close to our hotel near plaza Santa Anna. We showed up at 8:30 and the bartender said we could have a table if we finished by 10:30 which we had no problem with. The staff was very nice and we had the 20 euro tapas tasting menu. The tapas were all amazing and very fresh. The staff could not have been nicer and didn't rush us at all. It was a nice way to end our trip to Madrid.

review_preview: Vi Cool is located in a central street in Madrid, Huertas Street, which is plenty of restaurants and pub to have a drink. Vi Cool is managed by one of the most famous cheffs of Spain (Sergi Arola). The restaurant is well decorated, but the...
review_full: Vi Cool is located in a central street in Madrid, Huertas Street, which is plenty of restaurants and pub to have a drink. Vi Cool is managed by one of the most famous cheffs of Spain (Sergi Arola). The restaurant is well decorated, but the tables are too close to each other. What attracted my attention of this restaurant is the daily menu price (13€ without drinks), quite cheap and not common for well-know cheffs. The daily menu includes one starter, one course and a dessert or coffee, they offer you three starters and three main courses to choose one of each. All the dishes were made with dedication and perfectly presented. We would like to stand out the tuna block, which was delicious and incredibly juicy. The waiters were very pleasant. Finally there is a great discount promotion in a website, which could be very interesting for a future visit.

title_review: Best tapas, friendly staff, special care for gluten free options ...
review_preview: We found the restaurant by accident last Sunday (14th) and it was a great find! We all had the 20 Euros taster option and the food was consistently delicious and interesting. Our 19 year old described it as the best meal he has had in...
review_full: We found the restaurant by accident last Sunday (14th) and it was a great find! We all had the 20 Euros taster option and the food was consistently delicious and interesting. Our 19 year old described it as the best meal he has had in Spain. The best though was the care and attention they gave one of our family who is gluten intolerant. They provided gambas cooked specially without flour, knowledgable information throughout and it all culminated with the chef creating delicious gluten free patatas bravas that exploded with taste and were, if anything, even better than the originals. A wonderful meal - we will go back when next in Madrid!

From the outside it appears to be low key, especially with all the street rehabilitation. We stared at the menu for a few minutes and were eventually ordered into the restaurant by one of the staff. A trip through the kitchen revealed back dinning rooms packed with loud, happy diners, probably all locals. We ordered the especial seafood platter, picture included, or rather duplicated because it says it all. Was an outstanding lunch with local chatter and the splatter of crustaceans all over the table. One of my best dining experiences ever.

review_preview: Brilliant, authentic, delicious... all words that perfectly suit this little marisquería just a few streets off Calle Mayor.The freshness of seafood (in the middle of the Spanish desert) and the quality of wines on offer makes Marisquería Ribeira do Mino a must see for...
review_full: Brilliant, authentic, delicious... all words that perfectly suit this little marisquería just a few streets off Calle Mayor. The freshness of seafood (in the middle of the Spanish desert) and the quality of wines on offer makes Marisquería Ribeira do Mino a must see for any true and unassuming foody lucky enough to find themselves in the capital of Spain. If you are looking for white table cloths and struggle with topping up your own wine, this may not be quite suited to you... BUT if you prioritise what you are eating over how you are eating it, you must add this place to your to-do list! Service was excellent, food was excellent, location was excellent... what more is there to say?! Other than wine was also excellent... Looking forward to returning next time we are in Madrid.

review_preview: We went to the Maisqueria RdoM with one intention - to indulge in a Mariscada - a heaped plate of Galician seafood (langostines, prawns, shrimps, large crabs, small crabs, and the exquisite taste of the sea....percebes or barnacles!).  The Mariscada took nearly one and a...
review_full: We went to the Maisqueria RdoM with one intention - to indulge in a Mariscada - a heaped plate of Galician seafood (langostines, prawns, shrimps, large crabs, small crabs, and the exquisite taste of the sea....percebes or barnacles!). The Mariscada took nearly one and a half hours to eat, accompanied only by a full loaf of bread and a bottle of crisp Galician wine. Seafood at its best, freshest and most succulent - I wish they had this type of restaurant n Scotland! The restaurant is hidden away along a side street in the Cheuca district and is mostly the haunt of knowledgeable locals, yet still it is difficult to secure a table unless you pre-book or turn-up early (or earlier than the normal Spaniard). The place is a buzz, busy and bursting with emblems of the sea. There are a few tables at the front beside the bar, but most head for the two rooms at the back which are separated from the bar by the kitchen area. One of my favourite and most atmospheric seafood restaurants in the world!

We ordered crabs and prawns, and the staff even showed them to us before cooking them. They were also upfront about the individual prices for seafood based on weight. After that, we were served a range of dishes - I was particularly impressed by the Galician soup, and the barbequed prawns, which were full of flavour and not overcooked. The sea crab was wonderful as well. Their desserts are simple but delicious, which was just what we needed after stuffing ourselves.

review_preview: As a huge Sergi Arola fan, it made my day to discover that there was now an Arola experience available only a couple of blocks away from my house. Although the novelty of the new Lagasca hangout may have already worn off for some (seeing...
review_full: As a huge Sergi Arola fan, it made my day to discover that there was now an Arola experience available only a couple of blocks away from my house. Although the novelty of the new Lagasca hangout may have already worn off for some (seeing as there were very few people there), those that did go on that night seemed to be having an amazing time, and so did I. Although the menu is more affordable and more easily approachable than the one at the Gastro, you'll find that signature meals like Sergi's patatas bravas and sweet & sour desserts are still present. With sizes that are no longer molecular and meals that are still as delicious, you'll be excited to share this experience with good company. By contrast, the waiters are more pretentious and less efficient than those at Zurbano, making their effort at politeness appear strained and unnatural. Lastly, do not expect to see the man himself as he rarely graces this cheaper branch with his presence. Rumor has it he's working on his third Michelin star.

Big platters of Fresh seafood for sharing with a chunk of great bread and loads of great Spanish wine. Good Value for money. Its not fine dining and its not for a romantic tete a tete! However if you are up for a good laugh and like stirrling flaming alcohol (Delicious - DIY Irish Coffee )on your table with a ladle ( there must be a spanish name for this , but cant remember what it was).......... just go and have fun dahlings! Our waiter was brilliant and we had a good banter with him. They even brought my husband a wee cake with a candle on it as it was his birthday. One of the best nights out we have had.

review_preview: Just got back from Madrid and tried a few tapas bars and I have to say this was the best in terms of quality and flavour of food. I'm completely lost with the negative comments as we had a thoroughly enjoyable night, the staff were...
review_full: Just got back from Madrid and tried a few tapas bars and I have to say this was the best in terms of quality and flavour of food. I'm completely lost with the negative comments as we had a thoroughly enjoyable night, the staff were most friendly, charming and attentive without being overbearing and intrusive, each one very pleasant and even helped me with my spanish throughout the night rather than laughing at me trying to practice! ( huge thanks to the staff! )Ok the decor is a little bizarre and may put some people off but we thought it added to the charm of the place rather than being a negative and after all you are there to enjoy tapas and conversation not stare at the walls. I'm sure some people may feel the prices are high for tapas but I felt that we had one of the best value meals here and begs the question why stay and order if you're not comfortable with the price, you don't have to pay it, you could of course leave.....and of course the portions are small, it's tapas! ( though I have to say I thought some of the portions were quite large for tapas! ) If you go here expecting lovely tapas and a buzzy spanish atmosphere in a bijou setting then you will not disappointed, highly recommend the coco bread with tomato, the patatas bravas and the spinach cannelloni, very yummy indeed.

review_full: We wanted to visit this restaurant as the reviews were good and also because of who owned the restaurant. We booked a table for two based on the recommendations. We arrived and we were greeted fairly coldly by a waiter who asked us to wait until the table was prepared. A waitress dragged herself to the table to prepare it - quite honestly, she looked like she had the weight of the world in her shoulders. We were seated and given an explanation of the menu. We opted for the tapas set menu for 2 people. (€22pp)  The food was very good! A mixture of vegetarian and meat dishes. We weren't given a lot of time to enjoy each one before the next tapas arrived. Once we had eaten the savoury tapas I asked if we could have a rest before dessert. Greeted with a frown, the waiter asked if I wanted coffee or a cake?!  Service is in need of improvement. I'm sure Sergio Arola didn't intend for such a poor level of service. If you're happy to pay for good food without good service and limited atmosphere - go for it!

review_full: We had been told some of the best seafood is to be found in Madrid, and after eating at this restaurant I can believe that. We had a starter of Galician vegetable soup, very mild and fresh. For our mains we had turbot with Galician sauce and monkfish, both were equally delicious. The monkfish was served with a piquant and buttery sauce and a tasty potato stack on the side. The turbo twas firm and delicate, but not overwhelmed by the sauce. Desert consisted of the famous almond Torte de Santiago. Our meal was accompanied by a bottle of Spanish rosado. The attentive, without being intrusive, wait staff certainly complete the picture of a worthwhile dining experience. Highly recommend.

review_full: Not an imposing doorway, down a side street with minimal signing but inside, wow!, one of those places you know is going to be great. Room after room of tables, lots of waiters in white jackets scurrying around with huge plates of seafood, loads of noisy conversation, scores of diners, mainly locals. Try the sharing seafood platter for 2 or 4 but first start with a plate of the Galician octopus and one of the hot roasted peppers, also to be shared. The boiled ham and sausage was great too. Finish with their version of Irish Coffee but on a DIY basis i.e. they first bring a flaming dish of sugar and alcohol which you keep stirring with a ladle at the table to keep the flame alive (no Health and Safety here!) then they add the coffee and tell you to keep the ladle going for a further 5 minutes.... then drink! The most expensive wine was an Albarino at !8 Euros. We had two bottles and the bill for 4 was still only 130 Euros for a great Galician experience.

review_preview: Unless you really don't like seafood. Amazing quality & value! Just as well my son called to book the day before it was heaving on a Friday night (13th May). We had the 'Mariscada para llevar' for 2 at 31e with a bottle of Albarino...
review_full: Unless you really don't like seafood. Amazing quality & value! Just as well my son called to book the day before it was heaving on a Friday night (13th May). We had the 'Mariscada para llevar' for 2 at 31e with a bottle of Albarino & 'flaming coffee' to finish. All for 63e (cash only, no cards). There were prawns galore, langoustine, crab, mussels, lobster & we couldn't finish it - the couple next to us cleared their plate & were gone well before we were done. I should have worn a bib for this - it was quite messy - they give you 2 empty plates each for the shells & replace these as required, also hand wipes keep coming - finger bowls would be need to be finger buckets. No chance of genteel table manners or any delicate nibbling here. The decor is fairly spartan but functional - table cloths are of the disposable variety. I don't normally like noisy places but it seemed appropriate here. If you have an aversion to seafood they do steaks & things but maybe you should try somewhere else. We had been up in Galicia last summer so we couldn't have hoped for anything better. The waiters were a bit off hand but helpful if required & I think this was more to do with them being so busy. Lots of little rooms & corridors all with tables set out ready for the next customers

review_preview: We visited the Ribiera do Mino on a wet Saturday lunch time and had the most fantastic cullinary experience! The plase was mobbed and the head waiter, who spoke no English handed us a numbered ticket and told us to return in 20 minutes. We...
review_full: We visited the Ribiera do Mino on a wet Saturday lunch time and had the most fantastic cullinary experience! The plase was mobbed and the head waiter, who spoke no English handed us a numbered ticket and told us to return in 20 minutes.  We stood in awe watching huge plates of seafood being rushed to tables by dozens of waiters. It was well worth the wait - the Mariscos for two and a plate of the most woderful Padron peppers washed down with the house white wine was literally one of the best meals I've eaten. The ambience is terrific - packed with clamourous locals and buzzing with chat and laughter. The mariscos was literally groaning with seafood - two spider crabs, two smaller sand crabs a pile of goose barnacles and three kinds of prawn - all boiled to perfection. Messy and trully satisfying! Go there!

review_preview: Was recommended by my brother's colleague as the best Galician restaurant in Madrid. It was promising as the display of seafood and meats on the outside was impressive. It also helped that it was 3 mins from our hotel and the place looked promising.The...
review_full: Was recommended by my brother's colleague as the best Galician restaurant in Madrid. It was promising as the display of seafood and meats on the outside was impressive. It also helped that it was 3 mins from our hotel and the place looked promising. The decor and ambiance was old school, with serious waiters dressed in old world restaurant clothes. The Maitre d' was friendly enough and the service was professional. I was expecting more out of the food, though. The octopus was tender and flavorful, but at 20 Euros, should have been fantastic. a quarter kilo of langoustines was okay at 18 Euros. The 50 Euro seafood paella was disappointing - we asked for the more expensive version that should have included a "large" lobster but this one was probably less than the standard 1-1/4 lb. It was scrawny - even the claws did not have much meat. I would've gotten more meat from an $18 lobster roll in Jersey City. Plus - there was no other seafood in it. A definite rip-off, even though the rice itself was really good. Dessert and after dinner drinks were better than average: my wife and daughter was happy with the Souffle Alaska and something called Filloas. He poured me a generous snifter of a really good brandy that set me back E14. That was worth it. Overall an okay experience, but not a good value proposition. 145 Euros should buy you a better dinner.

We had plenty of food and had a sampling of 10 tapas which were incredible, ending with fruit and chocolate fondue.  Highly recommend.

review_full: The three of us came to Madrid from Barcelona for only an overnight stay in order to get a non stop flight home. We walked all day and were very tired but decided to go out to dinner. Our hotel recommended Caja Gallega since it was in walking distance. Their specialty is fish from the Galacian region and the whole baked Hake fish and the turbo were excellent as was the large salad. The steamed shrimp were small and very expensive. The head waiter is very welcoming and speaks English but not fluently. He selected our 1/2 bottle of white wine and bottle of red wine based on our price range that i gave him. Both were very good. On a Sunday night it was crowded with families and we appeared to be the only tourist eating there.

title_review: Great mariscadas, great crab, all around great place to eat
review_preview: Ribeira do Mino is down the street from my apartment, so I see it at night all the time, and it gets crowded throughout the week with an almost exclusively local crowd (not necessarily from Malasaña but from Madrid). I´ve been there a couple of...
review_full: Ribeira do Mino is down the street from my apartment, so I see it at night all the time, and it gets crowded throughout the week with an almost exclusively local crowd (not necessarily from Malasaña but from Madrid). I´ve been there a couple of times, and it is really a great place to take a seafood lover. Keep in mind that mariscadas are served cold while parilladas are served hot, so don´t complain that your mariscada is cold - it´s supposed to be that way. Though it can be offputting at first, give it a try. The seafood is so fresh and so well cooked that I bet you won´t send it back. The atmosphere is very local but also very crowded, especially at night and on the weekends. You can make reservations, so do so if you´re worried about getting in. I don´t, but it´s only because I can wait the 45 minutes or so at home and then come back down. That´s probably not the case for you.

review_preview: This restaurant is a "marisquería": a restaurant that specialises in seafood. In this case, it is Galician.A group of us went there on a Sunday night especially to eat the seafood platter.Aside from seafood you can also order regular tapas.The portions are...
review_full: This restaurant is a "marisquería": a restaurant that specialises in seafood. In this case, it is Galician. A group of us went there on a Sunday night especially to eat the seafood platter. Aside from seafood you can also order regular tapas. The portions are pretty generous and the price is OK. Madrid is supposed to have some of the best seafood in the country, as it's brought in fresh from the coast every morning. But it's surprisingly hard to find somewhere that will give you the fresh stuff. This place serves abundant, fresh seafood.  If you prefer fancy restaurants, then this is not your place. It's a place to get your hands dirty, it's quick and simple. There were eat of us and we ordered 3 seafood platters for 2. It was more than enough. In the end, with food and drinks we spent just under 20€ a head. I would recommend booking a table if a big group of you plans on going.

review_preview: A different experience in the popular area of Ponzano. The place is inspired in a real slaughterhouse and it's aimed to offer quick meals with high quality raw food. With an open kitchen that enables you to see life-cooking, you'll experience a different way of...
review_full: A different experience in the popular area of Ponzano. The place is inspired in a real slaughterhouse and it's aimed to offer quick meals with high quality raw food. With an open kitchen that enables you to see life-cooking, you'll experience a different way of enjoying your meal that includes observation of the cooking process, self-cooking (being yoursef the one who prepares the "tapa"), and tasting great food! Accompany it with some "cañas" and you'll have a great spanish experience! Pros: The food quality is exceptional, and the restaurant concept the greatest. Plus it's located in one of the most popular streets in the city so you can go for drinks afterwards in one of the many bars in the area. Cons: The space is small so be ready to wait for about 30min to get a table on the weekends, but they'll make it more pleasant with a free snack of home made chips!

More Spain is hardly possible!

The room is very cool and does give the impression of a Dexter kill room - sounds morbid but it works. Food was 'to die for' , everything from the tomato to the tuna to the beef with vegetables that you cooked with the blow torch. Got very lucky with our dinner companions and by the end of the night we'd met some wonderful/interesting folks.

review_preview: Fantastic shellfish lunch in Madrid - we were looking for someone for lunch at about 3pm and decided to try this restaurant. When we arrived the place was absolutely rammed - people standing outside with drinks and a slip of paper. We quickly realised that...
review_full: Fantastic shellfish lunch in Madrid - we were looking for someone for lunch at about 3pm and decided to try this restaurant. When we arrived the place was absolutely rammed - people standing outside with drinks and a slip of paper. We quickly realised that you have to find the waiter with the notepad and get yourself a number. We were told it would be about a 45 min wait, but we weren't in a rush and decided to wait at the bar. Bar is very busy with locals having tapas and drinks - we elbowed through and got a glass of wine each for about 2 euros. When I went back about 15 mins later for another, the waiter waved my cash away and gave us a free top up. We were seated after about 25 minutes. There IS a menu, but we decided just to order the mariscada (the cold mixed shellfish platter - ours was crab, langostines, shrimp and prawns) with mayonnaise and bread. LARGE amount of food - we're used to deshelling and picking shellfish - for us it's half of the fun - if you don't enjoy it, then it's probably not the place for you.... Lively fun atmosphere - we were there on a Sunday lunch, and it was full of intergenerational Spanish families. We were too full for dessert, but you get a shot of liquor on the house at the end. Thoroughly enjoyable and great fresh shellfish.
