title_review: Good value for loads of good seafood
review_preview: This is the place to go if you want a seafood fix. The restaurant is basic, and enormous, the staff are friendly, helpful and welcoming though be warned that they don't speak English so you need a bit of basic Spanish or good improvisation skills!...
review_full: This is the place to go if you want a seafood fix. The restaurant is basic, and enormous, the staff are friendly, helpful and welcoming though be warned that they don't speak English so you need a bit of basic Spanish or good improvisation skills! The seafood platter was huge. It had several spider crab sections, including four or five body shells where most of the brown meat had been removed for other dishes but there was enough left, and it was the best bit of the platter. Plus, a large number of prawns and about six or seven langoustines and something I'd never eaten before - gooseneck barnacles! They were so tasty! Real shot of the sea in each one. Bit fiddly to get out and they look like dinosaurs feet but worth the effort. Wine was good, and a good match, and seafood was served with lemon and mayo.  Worth a visit. €60 for two of us.

title_review: Best of 4: food, service, price ans owner's pride
review_preview: They do it with love and it shows all over the place. All the people work here are men (I did not see any women as far as I recalled). So when I was there at first glance, it looks serious. Everyone work on their...
review_full: They do it with love and it shows all over the place.  All the people work here are men (I did not see any women as far as I recalled). So when I was there at first glance, it looks serious. Everyone work on their role seriously. And then I started to feel how caring they are to their customers. It is not one of those try to impress tourists or get tip like some countries. But it is a genuine caring that even you can understand a word in Spanish, you know they care and they are kind. They are two groups of customers local who stay at the bar and tourists in the diner area. We stay at the bar because my husband have to watch world cup. I love a friendly atmosphere, real and down to earth. I had a really good time  And the food of course, the best sea food so far. We went down south but did not have seafood!  And the price is very reasonable for what we get.  We also got free shots of alcohol after meal.  Love it. This is one of the restaurant that for sure we will be back next time in Madrid. It is special!

title_review: Food is definitely generous, but lack taste
review_preview: Been in Madrid for 3 days now and I have to say this is my least favorite spot to eat.The atmosphere is loud with background music, and there was one waiter who was acting quite odd (doing pullups at the centre beam, drinking beer...
review_full: Been in Madrid for 3 days now and I have to say this is my least favorite spot to eat. The atmosphere is loud with background music, and there was one waiter who was acting quite odd (doing pullups at the centre beam, drinking beer behind the bar and slapping the tables). It might be his vibe, but I guess he was trying to make a rowdy environment for everyone. The food is very generous and big. The starters are like mains. The mains are like shared platters for 2 and finally the platter for 2 is more like for 4. So no complaints there, but the taste of the food. Felt like it was nothing special, no flavour, lack seasoning. Tapas in madrid so far have been amazing, exploding with flavours and the food displayed like a 4 star restaurant. This for me tonight, was not the case. Heard so many great things about this restaurant but tonight was not the night I guess. Hope you guys have a better experience.

review_preview: We booked a table here on New Year's eve for 11 of us - three families. Despite being really busy, the staff were amazing and went out of their way to make sure we had a great time. The restaurant looks quite plan - stripped...
review_full: We booked a table here on New Year's eve for 11 of us - three families. Despite being really busy, the staff were amazing and went out of their way to make sure we had a great time. The restaurant looks quite plan - stripped pine benches etc - but the food is really excellent and a treat if you love seafood. We ordered a wide selection of large tapas dishes which were all really delicious. The Pulpo a la Gallega was particularly good and the house speciality. We'd also highly recommend the tuna salad, the paella and the calamares. They have a good wine list - nice Galician Albarino for example - and we were amazed at how reasonable it was - especially on New Year's Eve. Highly recommends and next time we're in Madrid we'll be back.

Undeterred, we arrived at 7.50pm on Saturday night (10 minutes before opening) and were comfortably seated in the first wave of diners.  We ordered octopus, steak with egg and kimchi, padron peppers with bonito flakes, tuna carpaccio with wasabi mayonnaise, egg with foie gras and steak with pomegranate and mushrooms. All were absolutely delicious and my husband is still raving about the steak with egg & kim chi.  The atmosphere is fab - buzzy with loud music, but the restaurant is decorated with coloured styrofoam boxes that soak up background noise so you can actually have a great conversation.  Would definitely return if in Madrid again. A highlight of our weekend.

We enjoyed the shellfish platter for two (particularly the large shrimps). Fresh and tasty. Could not finish it. It was an enjoyable and unpretentious meal. The shellfish platter, two soups and a cava cost us E60. I would recommend this restaurant.

review_full: wandered passed the day before we visited and a guy came out, no pressure to come in, but answered some questions we had about things on the menu board outside. He seemed nice enough, it looked fine so we decided to go without reading any reviews. I have read some since and can't believe that they are about the same place. If you are looking for plush surroundings and prices to match this isn't the place for you. If you're looking for honest food, well prepared and served with good grace and humour then pull up a chair. The menu isn't extensive but there is enough choice, the waiters are brilliant, friendly and helpful,the food is clearly prepared by people who know what they are doing. We ordered veal heart (it isn't the actual heart but a cut close to it) iberian pork and a mixed meat plate for 2 - it could have fed a family of four for several days and it was all delicious. Very generous portions, possibly too generous, you need to take your appetite. The wine was good and the draught beer and both were reasonably priced. It was an evening well spent and I would recommend it. Muchas gracias por su hospitalidad

title_review: Good spanish food and reasonable prices!
review_preview: The restaurant is located a few minutes away from the Puerta Del Sol square. As mentioned several times before in other reviews here, the portions at Alhambra are quite large We ordered a typical spanish paella dish was good (but we tasted better). The portion...
review_full: The restaurant is located a few minutes away from the Puerta Del Sol square. As mentioned several times before in other reviews here, the portions at Alhambra are quite large We ordered a typical spanish paella dish was good (but we tasted better). The portion is generous and amount of chicken pieces was more than we experienced elsewhere. We tried the spicy chorizo sausage tapas which was again a large portion. The quality of the Sangria was excellent.The dish we loved the most were the Patatas Bravas, which consists of potatoes that have been cut into about 2 centimeter irregular shapes and then fried in oil and served warm with a spicy tomato sauce, definitely worth trying. The Alhambra interior is old and appears traditional, the service was fast and very friendly (although the waiters did not speak english). The prices are very reasonable, actually considerably cheaper than other places we tried.  Suggest you try it out if you're on a budget.

review_preview: I had read of this place here in TripAdvisor, and I was pretty satisfied.The place is informal, let's say it's an evolution of the classic simple restaurant with limited amount of dishes that are typical. In Italy this would be an "osteria", hence don't...
review_full: I had read of this place here in TripAdvisor, and I was pretty satisfied. The place is informal, let's say it's an evolution of the classic simple restaurant with limited amount of dishes that are typical. In Italy this would be an "osteria", hence don't expect high level service or environment. The place is crammed with simple tables, simple cutlery, simple everything: and it's PACKED with people. You must absolutely book if you're going for lunch on Sunday, and most likely also in the weekend in general for dinner, unless you feel pretty lucky. Unless you want to order something special, go for the seafood plate (I uploaded some images), which is a mix of different things: crabs, prawns, king crabs, and mussels of different types (some typical of Galicia). Prepare yourself to get dirty, this is not something you eat with knife and fork. Wine from the house is crap, but who cares, perhaps this is the whole point of the joint, to eat good and simple. Maybe you can end the meal with a nice warm glass of Cardinal Mendoza, a Spanish tasty and typical brandy.

An earlier reviewer is right to recommend reserving in advance.

review_preview: Ever since discovering Ribeira do Miño, my Spanish wife and I consider it the best seafood place in town.   You WILL need reservations for lunch or for dinner.    The place is intricate and cavernous and always full but the service is fast.   The monstrous seafood...
review_full: Ever since discovering Ribeira do Miño, my Spanish wife and I consider it the best seafood place in town. You WILL need reservations for lunch or for dinner. The place is intricate and cavernous and always full but the service is fast. The monstrous seafood platters (for two or for four) are delicious. We love the clams (any kind) and the Pádron peppers - again the best in town that we've had. You must not miss have the traditional quemada which is a Galician tradition - just make sure plenty of the alcohol burns off (you get top play with it with the ladle they provide) before they pour steaming hot coffee into it. A wonderful fun and tasty spectacle. Desserts are find but we especially like the Tarta de Santiago - very moist and flavorful. You cannot go wrong coming here for a meal. Just remember to obey the signs "Prohibido Cantar" (singing prohibted)! :)

title_review: Great meals for a great price!
review_preview: My friends and I visited Vi Cool for lunch. It is located in a small street quite close to the Palacio Real. I couldn't understand that we were all alone in the restaurant, since the menú del dià was offered for only 12 euro's! That's...
review_full: My friends and I visited Vi Cool for lunch. It is located in a small street quite close to the Palacio Real. I couldn't understand that we were all alone in the restaurant, since the menú del dià was offered for only 12 euro's! That's right, a main dish and a dessert for only 12 euro's! We got a huge portion perfectly grilled steak, which you wouldn't even get in any other restaurant, and definitely not for 12 euro's! For desserts, we got nice pancakes with a caramel sauce! The interior look brand-new and is bright, hip and modern. Please do not hesitate: if you are looking for a great lunch for simply 12 euro's, Vi Cool is the place to be!

title_review: Great place to dine in the new year!
review_preview: We managed to snag a table here on new year's day, a feat, given that many restaurants were closed in Madrid.  What a great place to have our 1st dinner in 2015!We had 2 tapas menus and 2 seafood sets.  As usual, our eyes...
review_full: We managed to snag a table here on new year's day, a feat, given that many restaurants were closed in Madrid. What a great place to have our 1st dinner in 2015! We had 2 tapas menus and 2 seafood sets. As usual, our eyes were hungrier than our bodies and we also ordered the steak tartare (nothing exceptional) and the salmon wasabi (also nothing exceptional). Of the sets, i would definitely stick with the normal menu as it had a better assortment of tastes than the seafood sets. The potatoes were a hands down winner. 9 beautiful cylinders appeared - crunchy on the outside and creamy on the inside; each topped with a heavenly garlic aioli. I would return just for this dish. The smoked eggplant puree was also excellent, with a mix of different flavours. The langoustines were also good. All of the desserts were good, so save room for that.

review_preview: I am somewhat tardy in posting my review, having visited in the summer. Noting that this was regarded as a "budget" Sergio Arola restaurant, I had been impressed by its contemporary look from outside when walking along Calle Huertas (just round the corner from where...
review_full: I am somewhat tardy in posting my review, having visited in the summer. Noting that this was regarded as a "budget" Sergio Arola restaurant, I had been impressed by its contemporary look from outside when walking along Calle Huertas (just round the corner from where I was staying) and decided one evening to give it a go. Prices are higher than average but clearly below that charged at the other upmarket Arola restaurants. My son and I both tried the classic tapas set menu which in the summer was priced at 20 Euro each. The Arola potatas bravas were very tasty and the fresh fruit with chocolate fondue was delicious. The set menu was a wonderful way to sample Arola's dishes and we were not disappointed. The restaurant was very busy which gave it a nice vibe. Yes, it can feel a little cramped when busy but the quality of the food compensated for that. I would definitely eat there again when next in Madrid.

Friendly, helpful staff and a great atmospheric hubbub about the place.

title_review: Excellent value for money and delicious food
review_preview: I was so impressed with Vi Cool on the last night of my holiday. I went on the recommendation in a guide book  I have which can be risky but it was great. They were very busy but they managed to fit us in downstairs...
review_full: I was so impressed with Vi Cool on the last night of my holiday. I went on the recommendation in a guide book I have which can be risky but it was great. They were very busy but they managed to fit us in downstairs and thank goodness. From recommendation by one of the staff members we had the set menu at 20 euros per person. There was more than enough food we could only just finish. The Caesar salad is the best I have ever eaten, the patatas bravas were exceptional too. I couldn't fault any of the dishes. The desert too (fruit and melted choc) was great to finish off. Sangria comes by the glass (a big one) and our total bill for four people was only just over 100 euros - great. Worth a visit for a Spanish experience.

We had salt baked bass. This was wild bass not farmed Greek bass. It was beautifully cooked filleted and presented. The wine selection was very good and we came away very happy. If they kept the chef and staff and spent £100k on a make over then they would queue down the road. Make the most if it before that happens. We will be going back on Friday for sure.

title_review: One of the best seafood restaurants in Madrid
review_preview: This is a 'marisqueria' or seafood place with Galicia origins. I have been to this place twice within the last three months. Great seafood at affordable prices.  A medley of different shellfish for 2 people (mariscada) with a bottle of Albariño wine will cost you...
review_full: This is a 'marisqueria' or seafood place with Galicia origins. I have been to this place twice within the last three months. Great seafood at affordable prices. A medley of different shellfish for 2 people (mariscada) with a bottle of Albariño wine will cost you around 50 euros. The second time around I felt that the mariscada was much poorer, as it did not include “buey del mar” or edible crab. Instead, it had many more tiny crabs and goose barnacles (cheaper than 'buey del mar'). I did complain to the server, who pretended he didn’t understand... The ambiance is typical Spain, lots of conversations floating the air, happy people from different origins. Not to be missed - the incredible velvet texture of “tarte de Santiago” for dessert, an almond delicacy from Galicia. Ribeira do Mino is located in a dark tiny street, a short walk from either Tribunal or Granvia subway stations.

I would definitely go back and also recommend Casa Gallega if you like fresh and fine seafood.

review_preview: This is a Galician treasure loved by locals and tourists alike (am a "lapsed" local).  The lower floor houses the bar, where you can eat/share tapas and sharing plates (raciones) in a more informal setting. The ground and upstairs floor house the restaurant proper, in...
review_full: This is a Galician treasure loved by locals and tourists alike (am a "lapsed" local). The lower floor houses the bar, where you can eat/share tapas and sharing plates (raciones) in a more informal setting.  The ground and upstairs floor house the restaurant proper, in a light traditional decor (but not stuffy at all), and a proper team of 2 maitres d'h and perfectly skilled and attentive waiters. You are also offered little tidbits (today: little slice of spanish tortilla and mini serving of "ensalada rusa" a sort of potato salad, and at the end, pesti~nos (galician fritters) The food is absolutely fresh and delicious, there are little things you won't find elsewhere (or even every day) such as scarlet prawn/shrimp (carabinero) croquetas, delicious!! The freshest fish/shellfish will be listed on the daily menu supplement. We had the cocochas (hake cheeks) and a hake steak, both in "salsa verde" (green sauce). You can choose grilled, baked, or even battered if you prefer. The hake was the freshest I've had in years, perfectly cooked, and melt-in the mouth. Other people around us were having deliciously looking seafood soup, an entire baked besugo (red bream) and renowned Galician beef (steaks, oxtail). If you are still hungry after all this, share some tarta de Santiago (almond based, very filling cake), here it is perfectly made. We chose a la carte and the bill was therefore pricey (€50pp with no wine) but absolutely worth it. They also have a daily lunch menu at 35€

review_preview: We spent 11 days in Spain, arriving and leaving via Madrid. We chose Casa Gallega for our first night and enjoyed it so much we ate their again as our final meal. Friendly and very professional service with white linen and a respectable wine list....
review_full: We spent 11 days in Spain, arriving and leaving via Madrid. We chose Casa Gallega for our first night and enjoyed it so much we ate their again as our final meal. Friendly and very professional service with white linen and a respectable wine list. Everything we ordered was delicious -- calamari, grilled veggies, seafood paella...all so good. This is an old school menu and old school service. Nothing fusion or trendy. Sometimes you want an experienced older waiter (and his 2 assistants) in a white coat serving delicious Galician! It wasn't that expensive, but if you want to reduce the cost, just order the house wine. It was great. Highly recommended.

title_review: Average cooking, but good value menu del dia
review_preview: My boyfriend dropped in midweek for lunch - the place seemed popular but not not too busy. Our first impression was that it was a little "style over substance". Our waiter was nice though and helpful in guiding us through the (Spanish) menu del dia....
review_full: My boyfriend dropped in midweek for lunch - the place seemed popular but not not too busy. Our first impression was that it was a little "style over substance". Our waiter was nice though and helpful in guiding us through the (Spanish) menu del dia. At 12.90 EUR for 3 courses this was great value but we were not blown away by the food by any means especially given the reputation of the owner. The food was all fine (no cause for complaint) but was quite average on the whole. The mushroom soup starter tasted great but was lukewarm. The bread that accompanied it came with tomato pulp and this was lovely. The "salmon a la plancha" came topped with a tiny portion of roasted vegetables (reasonable for lunch) but was also lukewarm! In addition the skin wasn't crispy which seems unusual for something cooked a la plancha. Chocolate custard/mousse dessert was a nice end to the meal. For the price, we were happy with our meal, but there is room for some improvement.

review_full: Don't expect anything fancy or romantic. The place is always crowded and noisy and you will probably have to wait one or two hours before having a table assigned. Seafood is good and comes in huge portions. The mariscada for 2 can be actually shared in 3. It's a great place for coming with friends. Wine is cheap, seafood is cheap and decent. The place is really centric, right by Fuencarral, close to Gran Via and Callao. I had a really good time and enjoyed the seafood. It reminded me of another place in Nice (France), le café de Turin. Cold seafood in huge quantity. The service is really fast, considering the amount of people dining there.

review_preview: We first came across this place when we were in desperate need of a quick caña after shopping in the Fuencarral area. It was early evening and the place was packed. We got a tapa with our beer and watched them preparing mariscadas for the...
review_full: We first came across this place when we were in desperate need of a quick caña after shopping in the Fuencarral area. It was early evening and the place was packed. We got a tapa with our beer and watched them preparing mariscadas for the imminent rush of evening diners. We decided to come back some time to have a proper sit down meal.  We came back on a Thursday at madrileño lunch time, i.e. some time between 14:30 or 15:00. Again, it was busy but we managed to get a table. We ordered a bottle of cava and went for the mariscada, an enormous pile of prawns, cray fish, langoustines, barnacles, swimming crab and crab. It was very tasty, but I was defeated about half way through. My partner slowly chomped his way through it all.  When he finally finished two hours later, the Spanish "ladies who lunch" sitting next to us expressed their admiration for his perseverance saying they had not expected us to finish. They on the other hand had worked their way through octopus and crabs and were now on some flabmbé desert which looked amazing.  When we asked for the bill we were offered the traditional digestive: orujo, a pomace brandy. At that point a couple came in and asked for a table. They were told that the place was now closed and that they would reopen at 19:00. It was only then that I noticed that we and the Spanish ladies next to us were the only diners left. Across the room the waiters had sat down for their lunch. Nobody was hurrying us although it was 17:15 by now and they had officially shut for their lunch or break at 17:00. I can't imagine this happening back home. We went home very full and satisfied. I am sure we'll be back during our next Madrid trip.

review_preview: Went there last week with a large group of friends (12), though we were a small group by the place´s standards. A noisy, traditional-looking place, full of locals and stressed waiters, like many popular restaurants in Spain. So far so good. Appetizers (pimientos del padrón,...
review_full: Went there last week with a large group of friends (12), though we were a small group by the place´s standards. A noisy, traditional-looking place, full of locals and stressed waiters, like many popular restaurants in Spain. So far so good. Appetizers (pimientos del padrón, clams and octopus) were good, except for octopus that was bland. Our host ordered mariscada, the house iconic meal, for everybody. It was so over-the-top that my appetite instantly went away, particularly because I had seen the plates of mariscada in the entrance fridge and had thought they were merely decorative.  I enjoyed the shrimp but nothing else. The percebes were tasteless and the crab bland and did not taste very fresh. Even my friend the host proceeded to mix the meat from different changurros (crab) to dilute the bland ones with the (supposedly) tasty ones. We left a lot of food uneaten.  The next day I felt nauseous and my stomach was upset for days. I also got an eye infection and a mouth sore. I would never go there again.

review_preview: I go to Madrid for business every three months generally and i never miss the opportunity to come here and enjoy their food, its athmosphere and the sorrounds.The place itself look yak at first, especially when u r not used to the chaos and...
review_full: I go to Madrid for business every three months generally and i never miss the opportunity to come here and enjoy their food, its athmosphere and the sorrounds. The place itself look yak at first, especially when u r not used to the chaos and the seafood smell. But if you breaks that wall and go beyond that initial limit , you will enter in one of the most amazing experience in Madrid. The quality/cost ratio is very good considering that abroad , in the western world, the same service ( a packed marisqueria dish for one along a 75 fresh ribeira ) would cost you at least double if not more. Service is great. They r very careful that you do not fill up your paltr with seafood shells by cleaning it up and swap the plate and they do not put pressure on u once u r finished. Whether you are by yourself or alone enjoying their delicatesse. I always try to stick to just the main dish marisquato, but green roasted peppers and pulpo alla gallega are also good to start with , especially if u join others around a big table. Just one thing: i'm not really a great fun of that highlighed yellow digestive, but it goes down anyway after finishin their lovely ribeiro ...and it's for free, so??? cheers ;)  Last but not least, the resturant  Position is conveninent for u to end then ur evening out for bars or straight into some clubs ;) ... But just after washing ur hands ;)  Ciao  Epi

Of course the routes of the chef will have something to do with it. Without reservation we had a 7 course tapas menu in a little less than 1.5 hour. The accompanying wine was from excellent level at very reasonable price. Being in the neighbourhood I would immediately go back.

review_preview: We hurried there as we knew it was popular and was recommended in Time Out. But what a disappointment1 The waiter was gruff and impatient - and seemed to be out primarily to get us to spend  a lot of money, not for us...
review_full: We hurried there as we knew it was popular and was recommended in Time Out. But what a disappointment 1 The waiter was gruff and impatient - and seemed to be out primarily to get us to spend a lot of money, not for us to have what we wanted. When we eventually asked if we could could have some butter with our bread - he replied that there was not any! - unbelievable. Then he left us to an underlying... The attitude was anti-tourist and antediluvian 2 The food about which we had heard so much was just average (merluza gallega which is a traditional dish and should be easy). I managed to finish mine - my partner could not . We watched what others ate - it seemed largely to comprise of huge platters of shellfish which had been ready prepared. Yet the place was packed 3 We left sadly, without leaving any tip, wondering what the fuss was about. We subsequently went to plenty of great restaurants in Madrid so we know this standard is not typical. The impression was of a restaurant where they had got stuck in their ways and did not care for new custom I can not recommend this restaurant

review_preview: Our second visit. Didn't have a reservation, Saturday lunchtime. Given a table in the bar just inside the door. Felt we were billeted there because we were tourists. Good fun though watching the crowds jostling for their place in the queue for tables. Tickets allocated,...
review_full: Our second visit. Didn't have a reservation, Saturday lunchtime. Given a table in the bar just inside the door. Felt we were billeted there because we were tourists. Good fun though watching the crowds jostling for their place in the queue for tables. Tickets allocated, numbers called. Queue jumpers, sitting at tables before their turn.  The place was packed. Our starters, a plate of Gambas and one of Clams were delicious. We went for the seafood platter as our main course this time, having seen its popularity previously. Not impressed. It is topped with prawns but they cover a lot of shell and little meat in the bottom two thirds. The Albariño was delicious. We washed it and the fish down with a bottle of the house white, which was a bottle too far.  It is worth one visit, but we are already looking for an alternative for our next weekend visit to Madrid.

We were seated next to two large party and they were so loud. We decided to order the seafood platter (38$), cooked langoustine (21$), clams (16$) and peppers (8$) + wine (21) (total= ~100$). In the beginning, we were super hungry so it was okay. Afterwards, we can taste the seafood platter was dirty with a lot sand and not fresh. The shrimp was soft and the crab meat was loose. The grilled langoustine also tasted weird. Only good dish was the shisito peppers which is inherently delicious.  Overall, I would not recommend this place to friends or travelers.

José our waiter was pleasant and luckily one of our party lives in Madrid and speaks Spanish. We don't know how central it was as we had our own personal guide! The food which was shared was delicious, bread was charged- sometimes it is part of the menu. Mariscada for 2 personas was shared by 3 people and tarta queso was absolutely divine, Platos tipicos Gallegos were the menu- if you don't like fish don't go but even if you only eat a little fish this restaurant is for you!! It seemed to attract locals and not tourists- maybe tourists did find it. But we would return- not expensive and we were able to chat despite the business of the place

review_preview: We had just arrived in Madrid and wanted a hearty dinner but weren’t sure where to begin. After some research we decided on Alhambra (a lot of stellar reviews) and they didn’t disappoint!!! The food was out of this world good, and so fast! We...
review_full: We had just arrived in Madrid and wanted a hearty dinner but weren’t sure where to begin. After some research we decided on Alhambra (a lot of stellar reviews) and they didn’t disappoint!!! The food was out of this world good, and so fast! We ended up getting the oxtail stew and garlic prawn (highly recommend both) as well as the smoked cod roasted vegetable toast which we just didn’t actually need because the other two dishes were so filling. The oxtail is served in a hot thick sauce flavored deeply with cloves and with a side of potatoes. And the garlic prawns come in a simmering vat of garlic and oil (with plenty of bread to soak up the deliciousness!) Not only was the food amazing, the staff couldn’t have been more pleasant and accommodating. They were funny and not at all cold which I feel like as a tourist is sometimes is hit or miss so we really appreciated that. Our waiter loaded us up with more bread than we could handle so we essentially rolled ourselves home. Definitely recommend while you’re in Madrid!!

The chocolate fondue was, well, a chocolate fondue. All in all, a rubbish meal with crap service. Not doing Sergi Arola's reputation any favours!

title_review: Food so flavorful, it makes you stop talking
review_preview: I have the good fortune of eating in a lot of nice restaurants for work. To the point of getting a bit jaded. There are rare times when the food is so flavorful, it makes you stop talking and pay attention. This is one of...
review_full: I have the good fortune of eating in a lot of nice restaurants for work. To the point of getting a bit jaded. There are rare times when the food is so flavorful, it makes you stop talking and pay attention. This is one of those places. We arrived at 8 am on a Monday and had our pick of any table in the place. We picked the one right next to the open window onto the street. Score #1. Our party of 3 decided to go with the tapas tasting menu along with a nice Rioja. Score #2. The dishes were carefully plated and the taste was crazy good. It's all we talked about as we sampled each one. Notice the "Uncle Sam Wants You On A Harley" sign when you walk in the door? Turns out, the owner is friends with the largest HD dealer in Spain and when you mention that you own a Harley (helps to show a pic), you get a 10% discount.  Yes, they brought the dishes rather quickly, but we stayed for 2 hours and nobody pressured us to get out. The staff were friendly and fun--maybe it's just us! I would make a special stop in Madrid just to go back to this place. It was that good. Next time, I'll wear one of my Harley shirts just for fun.

title_review: A place for locals, but there's better
review_preview: The Marisqueria offers quality seafood and is crowded by locals who definitely love this kind of restaurants. The dining rooms are large, noisy and crowded in perfect Spanish style. Prices are very, very good considering the amount of stuff they'll serve you but the only...
review_full: The Marisqueria offers quality seafood and is crowded by locals who definitely love this kind of restaurants. The dining rooms are large, noisy and crowded in perfect Spanish style. Prices are very, very good considering the amount of stuff they'll serve you but the only spot was probably the fact that fish is served cold. Cooked, steamed and so on, but served cold. This is something even raw fish lovers may consider a little disturbing but this is a very personal factor. If you don't like crabs, clams, and seafood in general this place is not for you.

title_review: Despite external appearances, this is an excellent restaurant
review_preview: You could wander past this relatively low key restaurant with a slightly shabby exterior and reject the restaurant on this basis. That would be a mistake.Despite the initial impression, this is an excellent choice, especially for those who like seafood. We hadn't reserved and...
review_full: You could wander past this relatively low key restaurant with a slightly shabby exterior and reject the restaurant on this basis. That would be a mistake. Despite the initial impression, this is an excellent choice, especially for those who like seafood. We hadn't reserved and were seated immediately as we were relatively early in the evening, although at peak times I would imagine a reservation is needed. The restaurant staff don't speak English well, but sufficient for us to be confident in our choices of food and wine. We chose the seafood platter and as the evening went on, I would say that about 90% of the customers chose the same. And no wonder. It is an excellent choice, as good as any seafood platter we have had anywhere else in Spain, France, USA etc., with about 10 different varieties of seafood in plentiful quantities for both of us.  We chose the standard house white wine and this was also very acceptable. And then when the bill came, it was a very pleasant surprise to see how reasonable it was. Overall we would go back to the restaurant without hesitation on another visit to Madrid.

review_preview: I called (in English and later in Spanish) to book a table here a week before and was told it was impossible both times as they were fully booked. So, instead we rocked up about 8.30pm on a Friday night and were seated immediately. The...
review_full: I called (in English and later in Spanish) to book a table here a week before and was told it was impossible both times as they were fully booked. So, instead we rocked up about 8.30pm on a Friday night and were seated immediately. The place was already busy but became heaving later on with locals and tourist. The seafood platter is the obvious choice for a beginner here and they seem to sell a good deal of them; it's a generously heaped portion of various shellfish as well as something I had never eaten before - barnacles. Prices are good considering the amount of food on offer and although it may not be tip top seafood, it's not bad, the staff are friendly and the place is definitely worth a visit. Booking issues aside, top marks for a great meal and experience.

title_review: Authentic Spanish seafood restaurant - No tourists here
review_preview: This place was recommended to me by a friend and I'm glad I listened to him. Slightly off the beaten track, The Ribeira is extremely popular with locals and I'm proud to say I'm pretty sure we were the only tourists in the whole place...
review_full: This place was recommended to me by a friend and I'm glad I listened to him.  Slightly off the beaten track, The Ribeira is extremely popular with locals and I'm proud to say I'm pretty sure we were the only tourists in the whole place one very busy lunchtime.  The menu can be a little confusing - what constitutes a starter and how much do you get - being a prime example. My advice is to think of everything as a main course, a hugely portioned main course at that.  Needless to say we discovered this by error and ending up eating our body weight in prawns , langoustines, shrimps and crab before our ' main' courses arrived.  The food is delicious - although all agreed that their main course fish was a little drier that we are used to in the UK.  Bonus marks for the excellent service, the unpretentious atmosphere and the very fair prices. Also note that in common with most Madrid restaurants tipping is not expected - just a few Euro's is much appreciated.

Not too many varieties comparing to the seafood platters we had in some other parts of the world. Apart from the crab, everything was nice. To be fair it may not be the right season for crabs in December. The crabs were not looked like freshly cooked, it felt like being frozen before as the meat was dry and stuck on the shell. Very good service and the atmosphere was nice too.

review_preview: This is a very traditional restaurant, very popular with locals because of the quality of its food...and they're not wrong! I went with two people who were not big seafood lovers....big mistake because the platter is really a must, but is served for two persons...so...
review_full: This is a very traditional restaurant, very popular with locals because of the quality of its food...and they're not wrong! I went with two people who were not big seafood lovers....big mistake because the platter is really a must, but is served for two persons...so I was denied it! Having said that the hake with salsa verde was very good trencherman's fayre, washed down by a terrific Albarino recommended by the waiter and the excellent cheeseboard (containing possibly the best membrillo I have tasted) meant that it was belt loosening time. The staff are very friendly and attentive without being overbearing and supplied free digestifs with the bill, which in itself, was reasonable. If you are hungry this is the place to go....but do remember to take a partner who likes seafood platter!!

The platter consisted of a huge heap of crab, shrimp, sea crawfish and percebes (goose barnacle). This was a real feast. The amount was so huge that I would not recommend ordering any other dishes to go with it. And it was very reasonably priced (15 euros per person). Highly recommend it to try.

review_preview: We have been eating at this restaurant for over thirty years and it is a compulsory visit for us on our Madrid itinerary. We were first taken by Spanish friends and were gob-smacked by the quality of its seafood, atmosphere and fair prices. Nothing seems...
review_full: We have been eating at this restaurant for over thirty years and it is a compulsory visit for us on our Madrid itinerary. We were first taken by Spanish friends and were gob-smacked by the quality of its seafood, atmosphere and fair prices. Nothing seems to have changed - the buzz is good, the staff helpful and efficient, and the prices compared to other marisqueria are still very reasonable. It is most important not to rush your meal but enjoy every course savouring the flavours of each dish. The house wine is also excellent and great value. I cannot commend the establishment more highly than say that this must be a bit of fish Heaven on Earth

review_preview: We were skeptical of this restaurant because of its proximity to Gran Via and the possibility that its a tourist trap but decided to give it a go based on past reviews. Are we glad we did!! The service was great and friendly and the...
review_full: We were skeptical of this restaurant because of its proximity to Gran Via and the possibility that its a tourist trap but decided to give it a go based on past reviews. Are we glad we did!! The service was great and friendly and the food, yummy!! We were served an amuse bouche of chicken wings the moment we sat down. The server then patiently explained the menu to us and we decided on the daily menu - del dia - which gave us appetizer, main course, and either dessert and/or coffee. The seafood paella, an eggplant lasagna-like dish, and oxtail stew was particularly good. The portions were also very generous and prices very reasonable indeed. Highly recommended!! Thank you Alhambra for a lovely lunch!

title_review: Good food and reasonable prices at a central location
review_preview: We have visited Madrid with our 2 kids and after a tiring walking tour around the city, we wanted to have lunch around the city center. Based on experience, it is usually difficult to find real local food and the prices are artificially high around...
review_full: We have visited Madrid with our 2 kids and after a tiring walking tour around the city, we wanted to have lunch around the city center. Based on experience, it is usually difficult to find real local food and the prices are artificially high around the city centers of other European capitals. After some review, we found Alhambra restaurant where we could taste local food and relax during the day. The variety and the quality of the food was more than we expected in a touristic site, the plates offered in the set menu were generous enough and the prices were very resonable. Moreover, we were also quite satisfied with the service and the cleanness of the restaurant. Only, it would be better if the waitress asked us how we wanted the steak to be cooked (rare or medium?). Overall, I can recommend Alhambra restaurant to people visiting Madrid, with its central location, good food and reasonable prices.

Restaurant - cosy, Mediterranean feel, live lobsters in the fish tank. Waiters - old skool spanish waiters who speak no english but serve tables how they used to be served years ago, when people cared about their jobs. Food - best octopus i have ever eaten. We tried Sea Pike for the first time and it was superb. Even the desert was great and all portions were decent. If you appreciate good quality food then this place needs a visit.

review_preview: Well, we've never had tapas quite like this!  We visited Vi Cool while we were in Madrid celebrating our 26th Wedding Anniversary and were so glad we chose that restaurant (the Lonely Planet write-up sounded intriguing).  We went for the six-dish tapas menu, which was...
review_full: Well, we've never had tapas quite like this! We visited Vi Cool while we were in Madrid celebrating our 26th Wedding Anniversary and were so glad we chose that restaurant (the Lonely Planet write-up sounded intriguing). We went for the six-dish tapas menu, which was loosely structured as starter/main/dessert, and every single dish was fantastic whilst at the same time nothing like any "normal" tapas dishes we've had before. Carpaccio of Portobello Mushrooms, marinated in truffle oil and served with grated parmesan and pine nuts was just one delicious example. Service was friendly and welcoming and we were pointed in the direction of a lovely bottle of wine which was actually one of the less expensive options, but which complemented the food really well. The final pleasant surprise was the bill - that meal would have cost at least twice as much in one of the upmarket tapas bars of London. If/when we're next in Madrid, we'll definitely be making a return visit.

review_preview: I would highly recommend this restaurant. We went there for the first time on Saturday evening and had a splendid meal of goose barnacles followed by Sea Bass cooked in salt. Both dishes were superb especially the sea bass, cooked so well and very moist....
review_full: I would highly recommend this restaurant. We went there for the first time on Saturday evening and had a splendid meal of goose barnacles followed by Sea Bass cooked in salt. Both dishes were superb especially the sea bass, cooked so well and very moist. It is an art form serving this dish and full marks to the waiter who had to remove the salt crust and then serve the fillets on two plates. There were no bones and not a trace of the salt crust. We were so impressed we went again the following evening and had grilled seafood consisting of prawns longastines squid mussels and scallops all cooked beautifully. Would also recommend the cheese plate and the tiramisu to finish off the meal. The tiramisu was beautiful and so very tasty. Next time we visit Madrid we shall certainly be visiting Casa Gallega.

review_preview: We came here after reading a rave review for restaurants in Malasaña / Chueca in Lonely Planet and then subsequent affirmation on TripAdvisor. Honestly though, not sure how to rate this place.  Clearly we didn't think as much of it as a number of people...
review_full: We came here after reading a rave review for restaurants in Malasaña / Chueca in Lonely Planet and then subsequent affirmation on TripAdvisor. Honestly though, not sure how to rate this place. Clearly we didn't think as much of it as a number of people on TripAdvisor do.  We ordered the 'especial', the seafood platter, based on the recommendations of TripAdvisor and the fact that many others were having the same in the restaurant. The platter consists of prawns, langoustines, crab (2 types) shell, legs and claws. The platter is served cold, which isn't what we were expecting. Moreover though, the flavour was quite disappointing: much of the crab was just salty in taste. Some of the crab she'll also contained no or very little meat, which was quite a disappointment.  Service was ok: staff were a little brusque, which I can understand given how busy they were, but they did their best to find us a table when we hadn't reserved.  Overall, I don't think we'd come back here again. We both love shellfish and fish in general, but the quality and taste of the platter wasn't enough in our experience to warrant a repeat visit.

title_review: Great seafood in a very busy restaurant
review_preview: This is a great place to enjoy Galician seafood at its very best, but is always extremely busy so not somewhere to go if you're looking for a quiet place to dine! The waiters are very efficient, but are rushed off their feet and can...
review_full: This is a great place to enjoy Galician seafood at its very best, but is always extremely busy so not somewhere to go if you're looking for a quiet place to dine! The waiters are very efficient, but are rushed off their feet and can seem a bit brusque. I went with my cousin (who lives in Madrid) and when we tried to book on the day we were told we couldn't but were advised to arrive very early (by Madrid standards), between 8.30 and 9.00 pm. We got there about 8.45 pm and only a few of the many tables were still empty and the place was completely full by the time our main course (the delicious seafood platter for two) was served.. We chose the tasty octopus tapa to share as a starter, and washed our meal down with the excellent Albariño white wine. The seafood is messy to eat, but was really fresh and tasty - unfortunately we weren't given wet wipes though noticed that some tables were - and I ate things I hadn't tried before.  I'll certainly eat here again next time I'm in Madrid, but will probably make my own selection of dishes as I got a little bored with removing shells and picking at crab legs and claws before we'd worked our way through the enormous platter!!!

My opinion is strongly influenced on quality vs price, while the price was steeper than your standard Galician restaurant, the quality just wasn't there.

title_review: A very nice traditional seafood restaurant
review_preview: This restaurant has existed since 1915. Love this place, excellent service, quiet atmosphere, and traditional decor. Started with an amuse bouche, corquettes de morue, tasty and nice texture. The portion of house salad is big and has an interesting combination, tuna, egg, mango, pickled pepper,...
review_full: This restaurant has existed since 1915. Love this place, excellent service, quiet atmosphere, and traditional decor. Started with an amuse bouche, corquettes de morue, tasty and nice texture. The portion of house salad is big and has an interesting combination, tuna, egg, mango, pickled pepper, tomato, avocado and greens, refreshing and quite filling. The seafood platter is so fresh that I feel the taste of seawater, good portion and with variety too. Ended the meal with the yummy soufflé Alaska, and enjoyed the show the waiter put on for us, putting the dessert flambé.

review_full: I would like to recommend everyone this place, either you are a seafood lover or not simply because a generally expensive food turns into an extraordinary quality-price relation. The restaurant is located in a perpendicular street to Fuencarral and it is always as crowded as people expect to be so making a reservation is essential . There is a parking just walking down the same street which it is really useful since it is completely impossible to find place in that zone. Related to the food, there are two main dishes, the seafood dish and the grilled one, which I would recommend if this food is not your cup of tea because of the taste mixed with their own sauce really tastes good, far away from the rawness of the fresh seafood. The dessert was the awesome icing on the cake. Bustling atmosphere and the waiters make yourself at home so it is really worth a visit!

review_preview: A couple of steps away from the busy Calle de Fuencarral, we expected this restaurant to be expensive. But it is not. Expect big servings, no nonsense atmosphere. The tables are packed tightly together, the decor very basic with bright white fluorescent lights. But the...
review_full: A couple of steps away from the busy Calle de Fuencarral, we expected this restaurant to be expensive. But it is not. Expect big servings, no nonsense atmosphere. The tables are packed tightly together, the decor very basic with bright white fluorescent lights.  But the seafood is good, simple and fresh. Most people seem to order the seafood platter, heaped with all kinds of prawns and crabs. There is no sauce on it, just a side of mayo and a chunk of bread on the side.  It was so good that we decided to visit again the following day and try the hot dishes. So if you a large group, add on a plate of pimiento (green peppers) and octopus. It is VERY good. The peppers are not spicy at all. Very flavorful and addictive! Service is very fast. The waiters are attentive, but they do not speak much english. The menu is not in english as well, but the pictures are a good guide. They may seem a little curt but it is because they are so busy. A smile will gain bigger smiles from them at the end of the meal - probably also they are pleased that we ate so much! Service is very fast - especially if you order the seafood platter.  We did not try the dessert, but from other tables we noted the desserts are very big as well.

review_preview: I found this place by coincidence. I went there last night. Book a table in the afternoon to be sure to get a table as I knew it would be full.What to say? Indeed a great experience. It is a sort of traditional restaurant...
review_full: I found this place by coincidence. I went there last night. Book a table in the afternoon to be sure to get a table as I knew it would be full. What to say? Indeed a great experience. It is a sort of traditional restaurant what in Italy is known as Osteria. Very simple, but clean place with a very friendly atmosphere. Staff helps you and they are very friendly although they speak little English. As I expected, after less than 30 minutes, restaurant was full and people had to wait outside: tourists and local.  I had the speciality of restaurant: that's a huge plate of cold seafood plus a plate of 6 oysters. 3 glasses of good Spanish wine. All simply amazing and at reasonable price. Strongly recommended if you are spending few days in Madrid.

review_preview: We stayed in Madrid for a week and decided to go to Vi Cool on the last evening.  We wish we had gone sooner. We had the tapas menu for 20 Euros.   This had been recommended to us.  This may not be what one would...
review_full: We stayed in Madrid for a week and decided to go to Vi Cool on the last evening. We wish we had gone sooner. We had the tapas menu for 20 Euros. This had been recommended to us. This may not be what one would traditionally think of as Spanish tapas, but the meal was excellent. The ingredients were top quality. The meal was also a bargain. The meal included salmon, Cesar salad, meatballs and fondue sauce, fancy potato tapas, incredibly delicious chicken wings (I usually don't like them) and fresh fruit with a chocolate fondue. The server recommended some wonderful wine that was reasonably priced. It is a small place but we were glad that this didn't prevent us from eating there. We loved the meal and the place. The service was excellent and English and Spanish are spoken.

review_full: My husband and I are staying in one of the apartments upstairs and the owner recommended this restaurant. The power went out in the building about ten minutes before our dinner reservation last night, but we decided to stay. We both ordered the tapas menu, but due to the power outage, the chef had to make some changes. He wasn't able to make the patatas bravas so he gave us an Iberica jamon carpaccio instead--delicious. He also added an eggplant dish and sardines. Both were outstanding and the presentation was delightful. The waitstaff was attentive and courteous. We enjoyed our meal so much that we are returning on Sunday!

review_preview: Another positive voice in amongst the mixed reviews. We couldn't understand the negative feedback the place got. It's not the budget option, but it's not ruinous by any means either.We had the 20€ menu, and the food was very good. There was meticulous attention...
review_full: Another positive voice in amongst the mixed reviews. We couldn't understand the negative feedback the place got. It's not the budget option, but it's not ruinous by any means either. We had the 20€ menu, and the food was very good. There was meticulous attention to detail on even down to the temperature at which things were served (the aubergine was a nicely judged warm, rather than hot or cold) and texture. On a food level, I would say the chef's real knack is for balancing flavours and textures rather than the exact flavours themselves. That is to say, if you gave him two ingredients I'd bet that he'd come up with the right way to set them against or with each other. It's certainly not traditional tapas, and neither is it outlandishly clever, but it's different, well conceived and very well executed. Top marks.

title_review: Very nice Tapas, but rather expensive...

review_full: I went to this restaurant twice during my week long stay in Madrid - once on business. I was surprised by the new approach to Tapas and really enjoyed all but one of the dishes in the menu (the smokes eggplant wasn't bad, but not favourite). The potatoes bravas were exquisite, as well as the bread with tomatoes topping. All of the staff were very nice, polite and all spoke reasonable English. The only thing I found a bit disappointing was the hefty bill. But it definitely was worth it. I'll go there again on another trip to Madrid.

title_review: Have wanted to try it for five years
review_preview: I've walked by this restaurant heading to one or another selected by wife or friends, but tonight was in Madrid alone and finally tried it.  I am fond of Gallegan cuisine and wanted to see how it fared away from home.  I was not disappointed....
review_full: I've walked by this restaurant heading to one or another selected by wife or friends, but tonight was in Madrid alone and finally tried it. I am fond of Gallegan cuisine and wanted to see how it fared away from home. I was not disappointed. I ordered the "Special Menu" which consisted of marinated salmon salad, croquetas and a seafood paella accompanied by a half bottle of Rioja Crianza, finished off with a tarta Santiago (almond cake). The first two dishes were excellent. To be fair, my preference for Arroz Valenciana prejudiced my opinion of the paella which was delicious and about twice what any sane person should eat. I just prefer my paella a little drier. I was disappointed in the carajillo which I ordered in addition to the menu. It was not prepared in the traditional manner, and while a decent cap to a good meal, would have been a highlight had it followed the traditional recipe rather than being sugared espresso with a shot of cognac. Service was excellent and the staff were welcoming, even though I took up what could have been a table for four. I would definitely retuurn for another fine meal.

review_preview: Went there and ordered the seafood platter, got a big plate full of shrimps, langoustines, other small shrimps (not sure what they're called), small crabs and big crabs with egg (love it!). Beware that the platter is cold as the others have said. The taste...
review_full: Went there and ordered the seafood platter, got a big plate full of shrimps, langoustines, other small shrimps (not sure what they're called), small crabs and big crabs with egg (love it!). Beware that the platter is cold as the others have said. The taste was salty and fresh, just simple taste but delicious for seafood lovers! My friend thought the crab was too salty but for me it was great :) There's plenty of seafood for 2, and in the end we took the rest home. They also do take away. I don't know if it's possible, but if you're taking it away, ask if they could break the crab pincers as it can be difficult to break it without the tool (i had my fair share of shells flying around). I saw some reviews saying they have bad service, but for me the experience was nice. The waitress was fast and nice. And i'd recommend to book in advance cause they are quite full. Will definitely come back to try the cooked seafood

title_review: Very good for the menu del dia
review_preview: We ate at the Vi Cool Sergi Arola in Ibiza last June and were hugely disappointed, especially because of the value of price and quality. But this time, at this Vi Cool, we tried the menu del dia for lunch, and with 20 euros a...
review_full: We ate at the Vi Cool Sergi Arola in Ibiza last June and were hugely disappointed, especially because of the value of price and quality. But this time, at this Vi Cool, we tried the menu del dia for lunch, and with 20 euros a person we had a full and very tasty meal. The problem is that the original Sergi Arola gastro restaurant is really good and expensive but worth every euro. These Vi Cool places, are not supposed to be expensive. But if you go for the normal priced dishes, then the price becomes very expensive for what is offered which is only a tasty plate of food but nothing spectacular that would explain the high prices. So if you can go at a time when the special menu is offered, go, it's worth it. Otherwise better save up and go to the original one.

title_review: A nice traditional and friendly tapas bar
review_preview: I found this recommendation on Tripadvisor and whilst it took me a while to find the place (Its down a side street and the photo on TA is misleading as its yellow and blue outside), I was glad when I did. The style is very...
review_full: I found this recommendation on Tripadvisor and whilst it took me a while to find the place (Its down a side street and the photo on TA is misleading as its yellow and blue outside), I was glad when I did. The style is very traditional and many similar tapas can be found in Madrid with the wood carved doors and tiled walls. They have a simple menu which was a little confusing at first. Tapas is tricky when you are dining alone as you either end up with too little variety or too many things. I had some chorizo off the tapas plates which was served on toast but was very plain and then some prawns from the larger plates which were delicious. a plate of 10 large prawns simply grilled. Whilst I dont think I experienced the best of the food as its better to share, the service was great and they were extremely friendly which gave the place a great atmosphere.

review_preview: An absolute gem, and a favourite among Madrileños.  As an expat living in Madrid, this is one of those places where me and my friends come time and time again.  Excellent seafood for great value (did you know that 'percebes' (barnicle-like things) are more expensive...
review_full: An absolute gem, and a favourite among Madrileños. As an expat living in Madrid, this is one of those places where me and my friends come time and time again. Excellent seafood for great value (did you know that 'percebes' (barnicle-like things) are more expensive per gram than gold?!), as they churn through such vast quantities that they keep their prices low. Great waiters, who love a bit of chat. The seafood platter and 'pulpo' (octopus) are particularly great, and finish the meal with 'quemada gallego' (which is a flaming coffee liqueur - delicious, and bound to put hairs on your chest!). Not a place to go on a first date - you end up covered in seafood from tearing crab legs apart - but it's wonderfully fun, and you don't get much more Galician than this!

review_preview: I wanted to have a classic Madrid lunch with my family, including my parents. I made a reservation, and we walked over after a morning of seeing the city. We were a few minutes early, but the staff was happy to seat us right away,...
review_full: I wanted to have a classic Madrid lunch with my family, including my parents. I made a reservation, and we walked over after a morning of seeing the city. We were a few minutes early, but the staff was happy to seat us right away, which was much appreciated as my parents were a bit tired. We had a really nice lunch, including a couple of fish dishes, the oxtail that Casa Salvador is known for, and some fantastic broad beans with ham. This food is not new school or pushing the envelope—and that's the point. It was lovely to dine while looking at all the photos of toreros and starlets. I would say that it helps to use whatever Spanish skills you have with the staff—although that is true almost anywhere! We thoroughly enjoyed the lunch, and I plan to visit Casa Salvador again next time I'm in Madrid.

review_preview: We spend a couple of months a year in Madrid and Casa Salvador is a staple stop. When I think of excellent Spanish food, this is where I go. Old fashioned dig decorated with everything Torero: paintings, drawings, dedicated memorabilia, and more in the Old...
review_full: We spend a couple of months a year in Madrid and Casa Salvador is a staple stop. When I think of excellent Spanish food, this is where I go. Old fashioned dig decorated with everything Torero: paintings, drawings, dedicated memorabilia, and more in the Old Chueca hood. The service is old fashion institutional: senior professional servers, crispy starched uniforms, the owner-hostess, and friendly serious attitude. The food is true to Spanish basics: Lightly breaded (Roman style) sole with fresh lemon, garlic chicken in a delicious thin sauce, accompanied by mixed green salad with oil and vinegar, and homemade French fries. Nothing new. No surprises. But memorable.

review_preview: We had a group of 6 of us; some Spanish speakers, some not. The non-speakers arrived first and the staff were more than happy to practice their English on us! And happy to rearrange the tables so we could fit the 6 of us together....
review_full: We had a group of 6 of us; some Spanish speakers, some not. The non-speakers arrived first and the staff were more than happy to practice their English on us! And happy to rearrange the tables so we could fit the 6 of us together. The menu was pretty basic, and not technically made for tapas - but the dishes were a good size and we ordered multiple plates for everyone to share and it worked out great. The food was delicious, the atmosphere great, and the service second to none. The only bad comment was the fish of the day - everyone that tried it wasn't a fan. Apart from that everything else was faultless. The staff also threw in some complementary drinks at the end...and we're pretty sure they didn't charge for everything! 7 or so dishes, plus some smaller plates, plus 6 beers, a jug of sangria (very nice), water, cola, then 5 desserts....and it only came to €100! Will I recommend this place? Hell, yes. And will I back if in Madrid. That's a positive!

review_preview: I am at a loss to understand the very positive reviews this restaurant has been given. We read about it on tripadvisor and were looking forward to our lunch very much, but what a horrible experience.  For us, paying 25 euros each for a menu...
review_full: I am at a loss to understand the very positive reviews this restaurant has been given. We read about it on tripadvisor and were looking forward to our lunch very much, but what a horrible experience. For us, paying 25 euros each for a menu is a big treat and something we cannot afford often, so it was also a dreadful waste of money. We were disappointed by the limited and rather boring choices for the menu de casa, but both decided on the potage to start with. It was simply garbanzos in a wishy washy tomato sauce with a few bits of egg white thrown in. Probably cost them about 25 cents to make two platefuls. It was edible - that's the best we could say.  Then we chose entrecote. Well, I have never seen an entrecote like that before. Slabs of grey meat, half of each portion was fat and gristle, and so tough that they could not be cut even with the steak knives. Not sure what kind of animal it was. It was inedible. The waiter noticed us not eating, and simply came up and asked if it was not to our taste, took away the plates and asked would we like postre. We just paid and left. review_preview: It’s never nice to leave a negative review, especially as so many positive ones exist, but you have to be honest about your own experience and visit and ours was very average at best with poor lacklustre service, forgotten dishes and lack of attention.The...
review_full: It’s never nice to leave a negative review, especially as so many positive ones exist, but you have to be honest about your own experience and visit and ours was very average at best with poor lacklustre service, forgotten dishes and lack of attention. The place itself is sweet. Authentic, local, cosy and has a family feel to it. It’s not modern, in fact very rustic and Spanish. With the walls adorned with bullfight art and pictures and matador photography. The tables are covered with red and white checked table clothes and it feels quite spacious over two floors but certainly lacking any kind of atmosphere. It was quiet and even when busier felt quiet in chatter. No background music either. The greeting was nice, if not a little formal and matter of fact rather than a warm welcome. The menu was fairly extensive and very authentic to its cuisine, which could be lost on those that aren’t too adventurous, but exciting to try. Olives are given to you, and complimentary too and are exceptionally tasty. Along with the bread too. The sangria is lovely and comes as it should with wooden spoon, fruit and a real kick. Very tasty. The chicken croquettes were delicious and the manchego cheese really very generous and tasty.  That’s about the best part of the meal, the rest was underwhelming, flavourless and bland. 1 main dish was forgotten completely and others alerted to what we had expected. None of the mains come with sides or accompanying dishes so order separate. The artichokes were soggy and grey, hugely overlooked in my opinion. No apology for forgotten dish, no rush to get bill or offer on any drinks, we were ignored for water and not asked during meal for anything else.  There was no farewell. Maybe it was an off day and I’ll just be one poor review of the many positives, as it’s clearly a popular place. Just not for me.

title_review: Old School charm and a definite local spot
review_preview: I had heard about this restaurant and there are quite a few stories.  Since opening in the 40's, Ava Gardner, who apparently had a thing for bullfighters, spent quite a bit of time here.  The walls are covered in pictures documenting the history of this...
review_full: I had heard about this restaurant and there are quite a few stories. Since opening in the 40's, Ava Gardner, who apparently had a thing for bullfighters, spent quite a bit of time here. The walls are covered in pictures documenting the history of this sport. I believe Hemingway himself said that bullfighting, auto racing and mountain climbing were the only true sports and everything else was simply a game, but I digress. So my wife and I were in the Chueca neighborhood and stumbled into Casa Salvador. It was lunchtime and this place was packed. There was only one table on the lower level by the door and one of the male waiters just was going to put us there. A couple of minutes later, one of the female members of the staff looked mortified and moved us upstairs into the depths of this Madrid home of many 2 hour plus lunches. First of all you need to be dressed decently. Collared shirts, perhaps a sweater, even a tie and jacket are pretty standard it seems, since many of the patrons are taking lunch during the workday. One of the specialties of the house is the rabo del toro, which is of course the tail of the bull who may or may not have met his end with a matador. The dish was pretty good, with peas and a good mushroom based sauce. If you find yourself in the neighborhood, I recommend a nice leisurely meal soaking up the history, cuisine, and local flavor of this institution.

review_preview: I would probably not have chosen a restaurant with a bull-fighting theme, but, fortunately, it was my husband's turn to choose a restaurant and he chose Casa Salvador! The cooking was simple and delicious: No fancy plates, no elegant garnishes, just well-prepared Spanish classics served...
review_full: I would probably not have chosen a restaurant with a bull-fighting theme, but, fortunately, it was my husband's turn to choose a restaurant and he chose Casa Salvador! The cooking was simple and delicious: No fancy plates, no elegant garnishes, just well-prepared Spanish classics served in a pleasant red-checked tablecloth environment. My husband raved about his veal chop. A potato omelette may sound pedestrian, but mine was absolutely perfect and is now one of my favorite food memories of Spain.The Madrileno families who filled the several rooms of the restaurant seemed to be enjoying their fried fish and meat dishes every bit as much as we enjoyed our selections. Given the excellent quality of our entrees, we uncharacteristically ordered dessert. The delicious caramel ice cream is obviously made either at the restaurant or especially for the restaurant. I wish I'd ordered my own portion instead of agreeing to share!

title_review: A must stop in Madrid! Excellent experience!
review_preview: We had a large group that was well taken care of during our dinner here. This was recommended by a friend and we were not disappointed. Completely authentic from beginning to end! We ordered many different tapas which included the blood sausage and ox tail...
review_full: We had a large group that was well taken care of during our dinner here. This was recommended by a friend and we were not disappointed. Completely authentic from beginning to end! We ordered many different tapas which included the blood sausage and ox tail which were our favorites. Our waiter was fantastic too. Make sure to take a short tour around the restaurant to view all of the photographs- much of the history of Madrid! You can see all of the famous faces that have visited this restaurant. You do not want to miss visiting this place while in Madrid. If I ever return to Madrid, I will be back.

title_review: Solid food in a spectacular food town
review_preview: A pleasant dining experience unmarked by any exceptional dining experiences. Our group tasted a selection of grilled meat, lentil soup, starters, garlic shrimp, etc. None of these items stood out in basic quality or even had signatures of the chef trying to make things special,...
review_full: A pleasant dining experience unmarked by any exceptional dining experiences. Our group tasted a selection of grilled meat, lentil soup, starters, garlic shrimp, etc. None of these items stood out in basic quality or even had signatures of the chef trying to make things special, either in spice or execution. That may sound worse than it was - everything was solid, traditional, but perhaps a little rote? The atmosphere was very cozy, with plenty of paintings and pictures of bullfighters and traditional woodwork, so it was a fun place to dine.

review_preview: As we were looking for a seafood restaurant in the centre of Madrid, on walking distance from our hotel, we deceided to visit 'Marisqueria Ribeiro Do Mino'.  Also it was important for us that the restaurant could be visited during the late hours because first...
review_full: As we were looking for a seafood restaurant in the centre of Madrid, on walking distance from our hotel, we deceided to visit 'Marisqueria Ribeiro Do Mino'. Also it was important for us that the restaurant could be visited during the late hours because first we went to a soccergame. We arrived 11:30 PM on a Saturday evening but the owner still welcomed us with a big smile. The fun part is, that the restaurant is sorted very chaotic.For example, when you enter you think the restaurant is quite small, but when they take you along to find a table, you'll pass the dishwasher, the kitchen, the bar, ... you can see everything getting prepared with your own eyes. The place was very crowded and have to say, many Spanish people and very few foreigners. Always a good sign! And offcourse, a lot of people eating means also a lot of food passing by. Very fresh! Finally we got a seat in a smaller seperate room. We ordered a seafood platter for two people. What you get, is what you can see from other reviewers. The tower of seafood is high, great, the taste is wonderfull, fresh and rather cheap!  Don't order the housewine but the more 'expensive' white wine (14,5 euro for a bottle). Really good value. We arrived in the restaurant at 11:30 PM and left the restaurant two hours later and yes, we only ordered the seafood platter! Slow eating with a lot of taste and also a lot of work to shell the shrimps etc :-). Trust on me, Your hands will get dirty, trust :-) We did not reserve a table but were lucky that they had some tables left! Please book in advance if you want to visit this restaurant!

review_preview: With all the hype about this being the local's favorite and it's appearing on a list of the 10 best seafood places in Madrid,  we were excited to try this local "gem." While the portions are generous and the service acceptable,  there's a profound lack...
review_full: With all the hype about this being the local's favorite and it's appearing on a list of the 10 best seafood places in Madrid, we were excited to try this local "gem." While the portions are generous and the service acceptable, there's a profound lack of seasoning: has anyone in Madrid ever heard of seasoning? The shrimp, crabs and barnacles were plentiful but they were disappointingly bland. The octopus, however was delicious and properly seasoned. Maybe they ran out of salt, pepper and garlic after preparing the octopus or the French and Italians have a monopoly on seasonings.

review_preview: Truly wonderful dinner experiences.  We ate enjoyed two delightful meals here during a week in Madrid.  This "traditional" Spanish restaurant is staffed by experienced and efficient waiters who only speak a little English but were charming in guiding us through the menu, which has helpful...
review_full: Truly wonderful dinner experiences. We ate enjoyed two delightful meals here during a week in Madrid. This "traditional" Spanish restaurant is staffed by experienced and efficient waiters who only speak a little English but were charming in guiding us through the menu, which has helpful translations for each item. The generous portions of everything we ate was tasty. We loved the beans & chorizo soup, fish soup, hake, cod, oxtail. After finishing our bottle of wine, the waiters continued to fill our glasses from the bar. On our second visit, we were greeted warmly, given complimentary appetizers, after-dinner drinks, and a gracious tour of the restaurant by Beatrice, the friendly and lovely niece of the founder and daughter of the owner/cook who died several years ago. We won't forget the hospitality and quality of this restaurant--our best dining experience in Madrid at a very reasonable price.

review_preview: We spend a couple of months a year in Madrid and Casa Salvador is a staple stop. When I think of excellent Spanish food, this is where I go. Old fashioned dig decorated with everything Torero: paintings, drawings, dedicated memorabilia, and more in the Old...
review_full: We spend a couple of months a year in Madrid and Casa Salvador is a staple stop. When I think of excellent Spanish food, this is where I go. Old fashioned dig decorated with everything Torero: paintings, drawings, dedicated memorabilia, and more in the Old Chueca hood. The service is old fashion institutional:  senior professional servers, crispy starched uniforms, the owner-hostess, and friendly serious attitude. The food is true to Spanish basics: Lightly breaded (Roman style) sole with fresh lemon, garlic chicken in a delicious thin sauce, accompanied by mixed green salad with oil and vinegar, and homemade French fries. Nothing new. No surprises. But memorable.
