review_preview: A shrine to Spanish Bull Fighting established in 1941. See if you can name all the famous Matadors or spot a portrait of Hemingway and the restaurant founder at a bullfight. Not exactly sure how we ended up here on the evening of Constitution Day...
review_full: A shrine to Spanish Bull Fighting established in 1941. See if you can name all the famous Matadors or spot a portrait of Hemingway and the restaurant founder at a bullfight. Not exactly sure how we ended up here on the evening of Constitution Day - few tables were occupied - nonetheless our waiter was exceptional. The food was fabulous. Recommend the oxtail or veal meatballs. Dover Sole was also amazing. Prices reasonable.  This restaurant is a little off the tourist track but only few blocks from the Gran Via. The streets are narrow and it looks like the neighborhood is getting a much needed facelift with new cobbles for the streets and sidewalks. We had to navigate our way around some of the construction but the dining experience well worth the effort.

The atmosphere is very comfortable, relaxed and very welcoming Even though the waiters only spoke minimal English, they were very patient and helpful. The menu has English translations which makes ordering easy.  I can honestly say that this is one of the best places to eat in Madrid. The service was great and the food was even better. My wife had the Ox tail stew and I had the Ox tripe and it was amazing. We highly recommend this place and we will definitely be back.

Needless to say we were nevertheless charged full price with no offer or gesture of any kind. Do not make the mistake we did.

review_preview: If you think there is nothing left of OLD SPAIN, think again !  To enter this wonderful restaurant is like stepping back into another era.  The food is terrific, the wine list wonderful and the service exceptional .  The waiters are throwbacks to the age...
review_full: If you think there is nothing left of OLD SPAIN, think again ! To enter this wonderful restaurant is like stepping back into another era. The food is terrific, the wine list wonderful and the service exceptional . The waiters are throwbacks to the age of gentility when to be a waiter was to have a job of honor.  The decor lends itself to taurine tastes but do not let that bother you if that is not to your liking as the rooms themselves are so charming .   The neighborhood is exciting and this is a rare find in the heart of an ever changing Madrid. As a former restaurant owner ( Riverrun in New York City) I value great eating places and this is one not to be missed.

review_preview: In a country like Spain, and in a city like Madrid, tourist traps are way too common. This is not one of them.The food is very simple - you pay 24€ (for one person, for two it's cheaper per person) and you get a...
review_full: In a country like Spain, and in a city like Madrid, tourist traps are way too common. This is not one of them. The food is very simple - you pay 24€ (for one person, for two it's cheaper per person) and you get a plate full of crabs, shrimps and other seafood. They are served cold, with breat and mayo. That's it. but the atmosphere is great - I was the only non-Spaniard. So if you expect something fancy - this isn't the place. If you want something authentic, this is the right spot. And like in any good traditional Spanish restaurant - you can forget about good desserts. Jiust take it into account.

title_review: Step back to a better time..
review_preview: Fans of foams and vegan dishes probably won't fall in love with this place but if you like traditional  stick to your ribs Spanish cooking steeped in rich cultural history then this is your place...I was tickled to get Anthony Bourdain's " table".. He enjoyed...
review_full: Fans of foams and vegan dishes probably won't fall in love with this place but if you like traditional stick to your ribs Spanish cooking steeped in rich cultural history then this is your place...I was tickled to get Anthony Bourdain's " table".. He enjoyed his meal here and it was also a popular haunt of Hemingways who hung out here with the famous bullfighters of the day.. My big plate of Manchego cheese, a half portion of the very rich brasied oxtail ( on a summer's day a half portion should do it) , bread, olives and a BIG sangria came to 25 Euros..a bargain in this town.... Great old school service included... Well worth the visit..Recommended for the solo traveler..

review_full: This is a small neighborhood place, not touristy. It features Galician seafood specialties. This includes a massive shellfish platter (shrimp, crab, crayfish etc) piled high. We were invited by a friend who knew the place. The three of us had octopus to start, two bottles of wine, the platter (could not finish it), and a "Queimada" - Galician punch bowl set on fire and stirred. All that was followed by dessert and small glasses of liqueur (compliments of the house). The price was very modest. We had such a good time we went back the next night and tried some other things - also very tasty and moderate prices. This one of the best "value for money" deals I have yet found. If you like seafood, you will love the place. Dress down however, as this a local spot and kind of fare can be a bit messy.

review_preview: Came because of the reviews, don't know what everyone is raving about.  We got the seafood special platter (prawn, langoustine, crab), oysters, and the house wine.  Yes, the platter is huge, and you will get a crazy amount of seafood.  However, it comes out cold...
review_full: Came because of the reviews, don't know what everyone is raving about. We got the seafood special platter (prawn, langoustine, crab), oysters, and the house wine. Yes, the platter is huge, and you will get a crazy amount of seafood. However, it comes out cold and very salty. No seafood/cocktail sauce, only mayo. Oysters were okay but very small and only lemons, tabasco to dress them with. I know a lot of you may be purists and say you do not need any sauce to enjoy seafood but for the price I am paying I expect to at least have the option. The house wine was very weak and watery, only good for taking the salty taste out of my mouth. The meal came to 60-70 euros. The place is not terrible, but for that amount I expect to come out pleased. I would avoid.

review_preview: Every time I travel to Madrid (which is fairly often since I have family nearby), I make sure to eat at this restaurant. The seafood platter for 2 is unbeatable in terms of quality and price. Very fresh. I was a little disappointed this time...
review_full: Every time I travel to Madrid (which is fairly often since I have family nearby), I make sure to eat at this restaurant. The octopus is also delicious as are the clams. I would stick to seafood as I've had family eat some of the meat and it wasn't that great. Always very busy so I recommend having a reservation for lunch or dinner.

review_preview: This place was recommended to us and we found it by walking from the other end of the, rather grim, street. We turned up on a Saturday just after 8pm, thinking it'd be quiet, since the Spanish eat later.However, it was already very busy....
review_full: This place was recommended to us and we found it by walking from the other end of the, rather grim, street.  We turned up on a Saturday just after 8pm, thinking it'd be quiet, since the Spanish eat later. However, it was already very busy. They did find us a table for two without us having a reservation. Tip: make a reservation, as when we left, there was a queue. We went straight for the seafood platter for two. Prawns, more prawns, langoustines, more prawns, crabs, barnacles (yes, barnacles!), finally finishing with more crab in its shell. Huge, just huge and messy, but delicious, although we weren't too impressed with the barnacles, there's not a great deal to them. After all that, we tried the Galician almond cake or Tarta de Santiago. This is very simple but truly fabulous. That was accompanied by two free shots of some yellow sweet liqueur (no idea what that was). This was all washed down with a 15 euro bottle of Albarino wine, again fabulous. Total bill was around 62 euros. Given than was for a phenomenal amount of seafood, plus pudding and a cracking bottle of wine, oh and water too, I'd say it's excellent value. This place is buzzing. Once you find it, it's not too far off the beaten track. We'll definitely be back, maybe this time trying something slightly different. We did notice quite a few tables having pimiento de padron for starters, then a platter of prawns. That might well be a slightly lighter meal. If you look at their website, they even do their seafood platters to take away! Very well worth searching out.

review_preview: I went many times to Ribeira do Miño, more than 10 times over 14 years spent in Madrid. Before going there it is important to know that it is a loud place, not very sophisticated, and you'll probably have to wait before they give you...
review_full: I went many times to Ribeira do Miño, more than 10 times over 14 years spent in Madrid. Before going there it is important to know that it is a loud place, not very sophisticated, and you'll probably have to wait before they give you a table, because that's what happen in popular places: it's very crowded If you want to avoid the wait, you need to come early around 20:30, or come at lunchtime in weekdays I would recommend this restaurant when you are with friends, before going out clubbing, so that you can happily wait drinking beers with tapas at the bar until a table gets free. I never went there in daytime, but that would a good option aswell. If you go alone, you might need to bring a book for the wait. They give you a number for the wait, or they keep your name. Maybe not exactly good for a first date, but good with your partner if you know you have the same tastes. Typical old style spanish seafood restaurant, white walls with tiles , galician decoration hanging at the ceiling , funny proverbs in frames. The tiles reverberate the sound, so having spanish peoples yelling jokes and the natural reverb of the tiles gives a noisy atmosphere, that is why every room of the restaurant has a frame saying "FORBIDDEN TO SING", you can easily imagine why ! Waiters are old professionals, so the they are straighforward and kinda rough, but always respectful. Sometimes they joke if they see that you are in party mood. I recommend having some beers at the bar, with a ración of ham ( jamón = smoked ham, or lacón = boiled ham ) or octopuss. Then order a mariscada for the number of people you have.  In this place a mariscada is a pyramid made of the following layers, from smaller and soft, to big and hard: - on top you have gambas ( prawns )  - layer of langostinos (schrimps) - cigalas ( Nephrops ) , these are kind of schrimps but with harder skin. - some percebes ( barnacle ) , when you eat these watch out not to spit the juice on the shirt of your date, or neighboring table - the bigger crabs : nécora ( sea spider) , centollo , crab , I never could distinghish them. You eat the inside of the crab with a spoon.  It is a very high caloric meal, so better to have a walk in the city after or go dancing to burn all this energy. All this seafood you have to open , destroy shell and skin with your fingers, or seafood tools and fork, while drinking the white wine of the restaurant ( vino de la casa ). Getting a little tipsy helps with this hard work. At the end of the battle, the table is full of waste and they give you something to rince your fingers. Now you can order a QUEIMADA, which is a mix of hard licor with coffee, sugar and lemon. It is like a ceremonial , and people of galicia have a spell to read for the fertility of the fields, used to be said by the Meigas ( witches). They bring the pot with hard licor with sugar, and put the fire on it. You have to stir with a ladle , until the fire goes out with the alcool ( they say, but you can simply shut off fire by blowing, and get drunk). Then the waiter comes wiht a jar of coffee, pours the coffe in the pot and you can drink the licor ( orujo ) with coffee. Sometimes the neighboring table ask you if you want some of their queimada, because it is a lot of alcool. If you have too much of yours, don't be scared to offer to the other table. Now with the beer atthe bar, the couple of bottles of white wine and the queimada you are ready to start a fun night of clubbing. For 3 people it use to be 60 or 70 euros ( Mariscada, wine, queimada) but it can be more if you order raciones or dessert

review_full: Taberna Alhambra didnt look like much from outside but hubby and I were happy that we did our homework and found this place. We dined pretty early, compare to locals, but it also ensured that we always got a table. This place gives you complimentary chicken wings as soon as you are seated and we were quite happy with the wings. We ordered mixed paella and stew tripe to hare. The portion size was huge! We could not believe how big the paella was, especially when it was only €7.5. The paella was full of large pieces of tender calamari and juicy chicken, and a few small shrimps. The rice absorbed all the yummy seafood and saffron flavour. We could not get enough of it. The tripe was pretty good as well. The tomato sauce had lots of spices and also packed a little heat in it. The only thing we did not like about the stew was the pork rind in it.. We wanted it to be all tripe...

review_preview: Within the vicinity of this bar restaurant there are any number of eating venues.  We were fortunate to have a good written guide to Madrid which pointed us to this establishment at lunchtime; that's after 14:00 in Spain.We established that the bar and occupied...
review_full: Within the vicinity of this bar restaurant there are any number of eating venues. We were fortunate to have a good written guide to Madrid which pointed us to this establishment at lunchtime; that's after 14:00 in Spain. We established that the bar and occupied tables were frequented by locals - usually a good sign - and by the time that my partner had visited the WC I already had received, without any request on my part, a plate of fried chicken pieces as appetitiser.  The menu is wonderfully short - which means that the kitchen staff concentrate on doing relatively few things extremely well rather than attempting to do many things half-well. We had a bottle of Spanish white wine - the most expensive on the list - and with three large tapas dishes of tortilla, meat balls and a salad, each of which justified the tag 'meal' in its own right, plus a bottle of water, the bill came to less than £40. The atmosphere was lively with a steady flow of new customers (on their lunch hours?) coming in for a drink and sharing plates of food with friends and colleagues. From the outside there is nothing to suggest anything special about this venue. The internal wall surfaces are a happy blend of textures and colours; much like the exhibitions we saw later during our time in Madrid on a visit to a modern art gallery.. What makes this a great destination for any visitor to this area of Madrid is the feeling that you are being granted an opportunity to see and experience a little piece of Spanish life.

We had a couple of dinners and some toasts, one with caramelized onions and pork roast drizzled with honey mustard and another with firm goat cheese and olive oil. review_preview: This has been a superb restaurant for decades. A hangout for Matadors and those who follow them, it also has excellent classic dishes of Madrid. The walls are covered with photos of Matadors from many years past. It was, of course, a haunt of Hemmingway...
review_full: This has been a superb restaurant for decades. A hangout for Matadors and those who follow them, it also has excellent classic dishes of Madrid. The walls are covered with photos of Matadors from many years past. It was, of course, a haunt of Hemmingway who introduced Ava Gardner to it. Ms. Gardner was known to dance on its tables. Service for an obvious tourist was attentive and professional. The food was excellent and reasonablely priced. Reservations are suggested and easy to make on their web site.

The Seafood platter was very impressive, top quality products and grilled to perfection and more than enough for two, so the men also had a share! The other plates were also polished off with relish. When we arrived the place was quiet, but within half an hour it was full, with lots of locals. I can recommend this restaurant if you want somewhere for excellent fish and shellfish and good service. The price is the expected for quality fish.

review_preview: After a long day of travel we were hungry,  tired and newly landed in Madrid we noted this restaurant and their fixed price menu of salad, starter,(or what Americans would call an appetizer), seafood paella, dessert and 3/8 bottle of wine for 29Euro.  The generous...
review_full: After a long day of travel we were hungry, tired and newly landed in Madrid we noted this restaurant and their fixed price menu of salad, starter,(or what Americans would call an appetizer), seafood paella, dessert and 3/8 bottle of wine for 29Euro. The generous portion and delicious food was more than two hungry ladies could eat! We took enough paella and both our desserts home which made for a lovely treat in the morning and more than enough paella for lunch the next day. The service is old world quality gentleman who did not speak a lot of English but we still managed to communicate even though we had (sadly) limited Spanish fluency.  The décor is dated and could use some freshening to add to the quaintness but the white table cloths and excellent staff, as well as their cuisine still make this a highly recommended spot for a good meal in Madrid.

title_review: An enjoyable and relaxing dinner - but be careful what you order
review_preview: We took pot luck at Casa Gallega after deciding that the San Miguel market was just too crowded (although the food did look delicious).  As the restaurant is very close to Plaza Mayor, I was expecting it to be a bit of a tourist trap,...
review_full: We took pot luck at Casa Gallega after deciding that the San Miguel market was just too crowded (although the food did look delicious). As the restaurant is very close to Plaza Mayor, I was expecting it to be a bit of a tourist trap, but in fact we had a very enjoyable meal. The restaurant specialises in food from the Galician region of northern Spain, so features fish and shellfish very heavily - be aware that there is a live lobster tank in the restaurant, so avoid if that kind of thing bothers you! And also be aware that neither fish nor shellfish is a particularly cheap dining option in Madrid or indeed anywhere else, so your meal is likely to be relatively expensive compared to the average tapas bar. The restaurant has an old fashioned feel to it. Service was professional and fairly discreet; at one point the waiter obviously felt we had waited too long for our main course (we were actually quite happy), so came over to apologise and let us know it was on its way.  All the food was well presented and cooked. Our Calamari à la plancha starter was delicious. The Santiago almond tart for dessert was amazing, as indeed was the cheese, and membrillo (although be warned, this comes as an enormous portion that I defy any one person to eat, so is certainly worth sharing). The only slight disappointment was our main course choice of 'Lobster with rice'. Nothing wrong with the dish per se, it was tasty and certainly filling (a lot of rice!!) but we struggled to see a whole 'large' lobster in it, as promised on the menu. To be honest, it felt a bit like a dish made with left-over lobster, and therefore not worth €50 for two. Were we scammed? Maybe. But the rest of the meal was good value (although not cheap) and the 'house' Albarino at around €18 at was very drinkable, so I'm giving them them the benefit of the doubt. I'd probably go back, and just be a little bit more circumspect about what I ordered next time.

title_review: A genuine Spanish oasis in a heavily tourist district of Madrid
review_preview: We found it through Trip Advisor so expected it to be good. We had just spent a long day doing galleries, museums and the usual tourist stuff. We were hungry and passed dozens of restaurants trying very hard to tempt us. We resisted until we...
review_full: We found it through Trip Advisor so expected it to be good. We had just spent a long day doing galleries, museums and the usual tourist stuff. We were hungry and passed dozens of restaurants trying very hard to tempt us. We resisted until we found the Alhambra and its fantastic tiled exterior. There was a very Spanish bar type entrance and we were greeted with the usual diffidence! Then Ramona from Rumania took over. Brilliant waitress, brilliant services and brilliant food and drinks. It is worth noting that many of the dishes are racions not tapas so quite substantial. The four of us have very different tastes and we were all really pleased with everything we got. And we also got the free liqueurs.  We will be going back to Madrid and back to the Taberna Alhambra

title_review: Excellent service and great food. Totally satisfied!
review_preview: After our Royal palace visit in Madrid, we wanted to find a good place that served quality meal nearby, so I came across this place from 4+ star above reviews on TripAdvisor. It certainly didn't disappoint! This restaurant was about 10 minute walk from the...
review_full: After our Royal palace visit in Madrid, we wanted to find a good place that served quality meal nearby, so I came across this place from 4+ star above reviews on TripAdvisor. It certainly didn't disappoint!  This restaurant was about 10 minute walk from the Palace Real.  When we arrived, we didn't have any reservations but the waiters were kind enough to let us have a table. We were given complimentary traditional potato cakes to start with and even though the waiters spoke simple English, they undetood us well enough. The waiters were all old school type, and you could tell they really took pride in their jobs. We want straight to mains, and I had the grilled sole and my partner had the escalope in egg batter. The food was of high quality and the fish was extremely fresh. The veal was soft and tender and was delicious. You could tell this restaurant really takes pride in the quality of their food. We were so impressed with the food that we proceeded to have our dessert there. I ordered cream crepes which was not too sweet, very fresh and delicious and my partner, really enjoyed his tiramisu. He is Italian, and loves his sweets so for him to really enjoy his tiramisu, speaks volumes! We were also given complimentary festive cinnamon donuts on the side which was a nice touch.  The total bill came out to be around 65 Euro, (no alcohol. Just sparkling water) which was very decent considering the good food. I would certainly recommend this restaurant to anyone who wants high quality good value for money food in Madrid.  By the time we left the restaurant was full and the waiters had to turn people without reservations away. Majority of the patrons were older aged / family locals, and not many tourists at all.

review_full: It was recommended to my daughter by an Australian colleague as "the best steak restaurant in Madrid" and it certainly lived up to that.It took some time to locate it as it is somewhat off the tourist track but it was well worth the effort. It presents as an old fashioned pub from the outside and inside like a small house which had been converted into a restaurant.The restaurant appears like a place that was caught in a time warp arounf the 1940's with the small tables all covered in gigham tablecloths and the walls festooned with very dramatic but gory bulfighting scenes from a bygone era.The clientele were predominanly Spainish business people .The waiters were very curtious but ordering was a bit of a struggle as they did not speak English so a phrase book at least is recommended. After several attempts they finally got the order correct and our advice would be to point at the dish you require on the menu and not to use terms such as "I will have the same as her" as you could end up sharing one steak instead of having one each.In the event the steaks though modest in size, lived up to their reputation and the flambe desert was dramatic in the way it was served and delicious to eat. The cost was very reasonable at €108 for 3 adults which included a bottle and a half of very decent Rioja wine.There was also a complementary after dinner drink provided.We would certainly reccommend it as a wonderful old worldy Spainish experience for dinner or a leisurly lunch particularly if you enjoy steak.

Finally I had the cafe leche. A great way to close the meal.  The whole meal was 65 euros so it was a steal.

title_review: One of the best restaurants in Madrid
review_preview: A small traditional restaurant, this is not a place that is made for tourists. It is an authentic Spanish restaurant with great cuisine and service. Our waiter Fernando was very helpful, he recommended a great bottle of Rioja. We tried the tortilla de patatas, the...
review_full: A small traditional restaurant, this is not a place that is made for tourists. It is an authentic Spanish restaurant with great cuisine and service.  Our waiter Fernando was very helpful, he recommended a great bottle of Rioja. We tried the tortilla de patatas, the ibérico ham and manchego cheese. All excellent. This place's specialty is breaded hits fish. Excellent, light, soft. Also we tried the on tail, ver good.  Homemade bread was superb and enjoyed with olive oil.  Dessert we tried their traditional fried cheese, that comes with nougat ice cream. Magnificent.  The decorations on the walls are centered on bull fighting and even though this is where Hemingway used to have dinner, it is not a tourist trap. It is the real deal.  Ask for recommendations from the waiters, they are ver knowledgeable. And do not eat much before you go.

review_preview: This place is awesome, every time we come to Madrid we eat here. They have a pretty decent menu, but we end up ordering the "Rabo Estofado"  every time (which is oxtail stew). **BEWARE** you will only find this on the Spanish Menu, it's not...
review_full: This place is awesome, every time we come to Madrid we eat here.  They have a pretty decent menu, but we end up ordering the "Rabo Estofado" every time (which is oxtail stew). **BEWARE** you will only find this on the Spanish Menu, it's not on the English translation of the menu. Very sneaky... Anyway, the stew is so good, slow cooked for hours, the meat just falls off the bone, and comes out from the kitchen almost immediately after ordering. Ask for a wine recommendation and the servers give you an honest choice without just picking the most expensive option.  The servers are a bunch of old guys who are super nice, and the walls are adorned with images of the glory years of bull fighting.  We will continue to go to this place on every subsequent visit to this fine city.

Try and speak a bit of Spanish - you will be well rewarded ( our brandy was huge ! )
